revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina altissima |accepted_authority=(Linnaeus) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 212. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=White snakeroot |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Ageratum altissimum |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species |publication_title=Sp. Pl. |publication_place=2: 839. 1753, }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina altissima |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina altissima]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548, 550, 551 |treatment_page=page 549 }}Perennials, (30–)50–80(–120) cm (bases usually fibrous-rooted crowns, sometimes rhizomatous). Stems ascending to erect, sometimes semiscandent, puberulent (hairs minute, crisped). Leaves opposite; petioles (5–)10–30(–50) mm; blades usually deltate-ovate to ovate or broadly lanceolate, sometimes ovate-lanceolate, 4–11(–13) × 2.5–8(–9) cm, bases usually rounded to truncate or obtuse, sometimes cordate, margins coarsely and doubly incised-serrate, apices usually acuminate. Heads clustered. Peduncles 1–5 mm, puberulent. Involucres 4–5 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces glabrous or sparsely and finely villous. Corollas white, lobes sparsely short-villous. Cypselae glabrous.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=N.B.;N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Mass.;Md.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;N.Dak.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Nebr.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wis. |discussion=

Varieties 2 (2 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Phyllaries 3–5 mm, apices not cuspidate |[[Ageratina altissima var. altissima|Ageratina altissima var. altissima]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Phyllaries 4–7 mm, apices cuspidate to acuminate |[[Ageratina altissima var. roanensis|Ageratina altissima var. roanensis]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina altissima |authority=(Linnaeus) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Ageratum altissimum |family=Asteraceae |distribution=N.B.;N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Mass.;Md.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;N.Dak.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;Nebr.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wis. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1390.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina altissima }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Ageratina]] [[Category:Revised Since Print]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina altissima var. altissima |accepted_authority= |publications= |common_names=Common white snakeroot;eupatoire rugueuse |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ageratina altissima var. angustata |authority=Fernald |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Eupatorium rugosum |authority=Reichard |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Eupatorium rugosum var. chlorolepis |authority=(B. L. Robinson) S. F. Blake |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Eupatorium rugosum var. tomentellum |authority= |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Eupatorium urticifolium |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina altissima;Ageratina altissima var. altissima |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina altissima]]
variety[[Ageratina altissima var. altissima]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 549 }}Phyllaries 3–5 mm, apices not cuspidate.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jul–Oct(–Nov). |habitat=Moist forests, cove forests |elevation=10–800 m |distribution=N.B.;N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;Fla.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wis. |discussion=

Plants with narrow leaves, generally in the southwest part of the range of Ageratina altissima, have been recognized as var. angustata and were so mapped by A. F. Clewell and J. W. Wooten (1971), who indicated that all var. angustata occurs west of the Mississippi River and that this taxon was completely congruent in distribution with var. altissima. The present treatment confirms the westward tendency toward size reduction and observes that narrow-leaved plants occur widely through the southeast United States (including Arkansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, and Texas). The transition is gradual and the region of intergradation is wide. In Texas, where the leaves mostly are narrow, plants with broad, cordate leaves are scattered through the range.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina altissima var. altissima |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Ageratina altissima var. angustata;Eupatorium rugosum;Eupatorium rugosum var. chlorolepis;Eupatorium rugosum var. tomentellum;Eupatorium urticifolium |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jul–Oct(–Nov). |habitat=Moist forests, cove forests |elevation=10–800 m |distribution=N.B.;N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;Fla.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Vt.;W.Va.;Wis. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1391.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina altissima |variety=Ageratina altissima var. altissima }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina altissima]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina altissima var. roanensis |accepted_authority=(Small) Clewell & Wooten |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Brittonia |place=23: 138. 1971 |year=1971 }} |common_names=Appalachian white snakeroot |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium roanense |authority=Small |rank=species |publication_title=Man. S.E. Fl., |publication_place=1326. 1933 (as roanensis) }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Eupatorium rugosum var. roanense |authority=(Small) Fernald |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina altissima;Ageratina altissima var. roanensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina altissima]]
variety[[Ageratina altissima var. roanensis]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 549 |treatment_page=page 550 }}Phyllaries 4–7 mm, apices cuspidate to acuminate.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jul–Oct. |habitat=Moist forests, northern red oak, oak-chestnut, cove forests |elevation=700–1500 m |distribution=Ala.;Ga.;Ky.;N.C.;S.C.;Tenn.;Va.;W.Va. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina altissima var. roanensis |authority=(Small) Clewell & Wooten |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Eupatorium rugosum var. roanense |basionyms=Eupatorium roanense |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jul–Oct. |habitat=Moist forests, northern red oak, oak-chestnut, cove forests |elevation=700–1500 m |distribution=Ala.;Ga.;Ky.;N.C.;S.C.;Tenn.;Va.;W.Va. |reference=None |publication title=Brittonia |publication year=1971 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1392.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina altissima |variety=Ageratina altissima var. roanensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina altissima]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina aromatica |accepted_authority=(Linnaeus) Spach |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Hist. Nat. Vég. |place=10: 286. 1841 |year=1841 }} |common_names=Small-leaved white snakeroot |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium aromaticum |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species |publication_title=Sp. Pl. |publication_place=2: 839. 1753 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Eupatorium latidens |authority=Small |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina aromatica |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina aromatica]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548, 551 |treatment_page=page 550 }}Perennials, 30–80(–100) cm. Stems erect, villous-puberulent. Leaves opposite; petioles 1–8(–12) mm; blades narrowly to broadly deltate to nearly ovate or lanceolate, 2–7(–9) × 1.5–4 cm, (usually subcoriaceous) bases rounded or truncate to barely cuneate or subcordate, margins usually crenate, sometimes crenate-serrate to dentate or subentire, apices acute to obtuse, faces minutely pilose. Heads clustered. Peduncles 2–9 mm, densely and closely puberulent. Involucres 3.5–5 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces puberulent to villous-puberulent. Corollas white, lobes sparsely villous. Cypselae usually glabrous or sparsely puberulent (near apices), rarely hirtellous on angles. 2n = 34.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late Aug–Oct(–Nov). |habitat=Sandy soils, burned pinelands, turkey oak sand ridges, pine-oak and oak-hickory upland woods, old fields, roadsides, fencerows, moist sites |elevation=100–900 m |distribution=Ala.;Conn.;Del.;Fla.;Ky.;La.;Md.;Mass.;Miss.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Ohio;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;Tenn.;Va.;W.Va. |discussion=

Intergrades (probable hybrids) between Ageratina aromatica and A. altissima were identified by A. F. Clewell and J. W. Wooten (1971) over a broad area of their sympatry. They also found intergrades between A. aromatica and A. jucunda where their ranges meet.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina aromatica |authority=(Linnaeus) Spach |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Eupatorium latidens |basionyms=Eupatorium aromaticum |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering late Aug–Oct(–Nov). |habitat=Sandy soils, burned pinelands, turkey oak sand ridges, pine-oak and oak-hickory upland woods, old fields, roadsides, fencerows, moist sites |elevation=100–900 m |distribution=Ala.;Conn.;Del.;Fla.;Ky.;La.;Md.;Mass.;Miss.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Ohio;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;Tenn.;Va.;W.Va. |reference=None |publication title=Hist. Nat. Vég. |publication year=1841 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1395.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina aromatica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina havanensis |accepted_authority=(Kunth) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 222. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Havana snakeroot |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium havanense |authority=Kunth inA. von Humboldt et al. |rank=species |publication_title=Nov. Gen. Sp. |publication_place=4(fol.): 100. 1818; 4(qto.): 128. 1820 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina havanensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina havanensis]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548 |treatment_page=page 552 }}Shrubs [trees], (30–)69–150(–200) cm. Stems erect (brittle), puberulent to glabrous. Leaves persistent, opposite; petioles 3–10(–15) mm; blades deltate to broadly ovate or somewhat hastate, (2–)3–5(–8) × 2–5 cm, bases truncate to cuneate, margins dentate, apices acute, faces glabrous or nearly so, eglandular. Heads clustered. Peduncles 2–14 mm, minutely puberulent. Involucres 4–6 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces glabrous or nearly so. Corollas white to slightly pinkish, glabrous. Cypselae hispid. 2n = 34.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mainly (Sep–)Oct–Nov(–Dec), also Apr–Jul. |habitat=Bluffs, limestone outcrops and slopes, ledges along streams, often in oak-juniper woodlands |elevation=100–900 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico;West Indies (Cuba). |discussion=

Ageratina havanensis apparently is the only species of the genus in the flora area with evergreen-persistent leaves.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina havanensis |authority=(Kunth) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium havanense |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering mainly (Sep–)Oct–Nov(–Dec), also Apr–Jul. |habitat=Bluffs, limestone outcrops and slopes, ledges along streams, often in oak-juniper woodlands |elevation=100–900 m |distribution=Tex.;Mexico;West Indies (Cuba). |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1400.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina havanensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina herbacea |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 222. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Fragrant snakeroot |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium ageratifolium var. herbaceum |authority=A. Gray |rank=variety |publication_title=Smithsonian Contr. Knowl. |publication_place=5(6): 74. 1853 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Eupatorium herbaceum |authority=(A. Gray) Greene |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina herbacea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina herbacea]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548 |treatment_page=page 551 }}Perennials or subshrubs, (20–)30–60(–80) cm (woody crowns and woody rhizomes). Stems erect (brittle), minutely puberulent. Leaves opposite; petioles 10–25 mm; blades triangular to lanceolate-ovate or ovate, 2–5(–7) × 1.5–3.5(–4.5) cm, bases truncate to shallowly cordate, margins dentate to serrate-dentate, abaxial faces sparsely hispidulous to glabrate, eglandular. Heads clustered. Peduncles 4–15 mm, puberulent. Involucres 4–5 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces granular-puberulent. Corollas white, glabrous. Cypselae finely strigose-hispidulous. 2n = 34.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Jul–)Aug–Oct. |habitat=Pine, pine-oak, juniper, and pinyon-juniper woodlands, rocks along streams, slopes, ridges, washes |elevation=1400–2700(–2900) m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico (Baja California;Chihuahua;Coahuila;Sonora). |discussion=

Ageratina herbacea is recognized by the distinctive color of its usually yellow-green, sometimes grayish, leaves, granular-puberulent involucres (with minute, thickened, eglandular hairs), and woody rhizomes.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina herbacea |authority=(A. Gray) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Eupatorium herbaceum |basionyms=Eupatorium ageratifolium var. herbaceum |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering (Jul–)Aug–Oct. |habitat=Pine, pine-oak, juniper, and pinyon-juniper woodlands, rocks along streams, slopes, ridges, washes |elevation=1400–2700(–2900) m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Nev.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico (Baja California;Chihuahua;Coahuila;Sonora). |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1398.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina herbacea }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina jucunda |accepted_authority=(Greene) Clewell & Wooten |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Brittonia |place=23: 142. 1971 |year=1971 }} |common_names=Hammock snakeroot |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium jucundum |authority=Greene |rank=species |publication_title=Pittonia |publication_place=3: 180. 1897, }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina jucunda |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina jucunda]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548 |treatment_page=page 551 }}Perennials, 40–80(–100) cm. Stems erect, lax, minutely pilose. Leaves opposite; petioles 7–15(–22) mm; blades narrowly deltate to rhombic, 2–6(–7) × 1.5–4 cm, (usually subcoriaceous) bases usually cuneate, sometimes truncate to slightly subcordate, margins usually coarsely serrate or incised, sometimes crenate to subentire, apices acute to acuminate, abaxial faces glabrous or hairy on veins. Heads clustered. Peduncles 2–10 mm, sparsely puberulent. Involucres 2.5–4 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces puberulent to villous-puberulent. Corollas white, lobes glabrous or sparsely short-hirtellous. Cypselae usually finely hirtellous-strigose on distal 1/3, sometimes glabrous. 2n = 34.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Sep–)Oct–Dec(–Jan). |habitat=Sand pine scrub, longleaf pine-turkey oak sand ridges, pine-palmetto, live-oak woods, hammocks, dunes, roadsides, old fields, stream banks, dry flatwoods |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=Fla.;Ga. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina jucunda |authority=(Greene) Clewell & Wooten |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium jucundum |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering (Sep–)Oct–Dec(–Jan). |habitat=Sand pine scrub, longleaf pine-turkey oak sand ridges, pine-palmetto, live-oak woods, hammocks, dunes, roadsides, old fields, stream banks, dry flatwoods |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=Fla.;Ga. |reference=None |publication title=Brittonia |publication year=1971 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1396.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina jucunda }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina lemmonii |accepted_authority=(B. L. Robinson) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 223. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Lemmon’s snakeroot |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium lemmonii |authority=B. L. Robinson |rank=species |publication_title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |publication_place=27: 171. 1892 (as lemmoni) }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina lemmonii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina lemmonii]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548 |treatment_page=page 551 }}Perennials, 20–40(–70) cm (densely fibrous-rooted crowns). Stems (commonly purple) erect, puberulous (hairs usually with colored crosswalls). Leaves opposite; petioles usually 0, sometimes 1–2 mm; blades ovate-lanceolate, 2–4.5 × 0.5–2.5 cm, margins shallowly serrate, abaxial faces glabrous or glabrate, gland-dotted. Heads in loose, open arrays. Peduncles 10–60 mm, puberulent. Involucres 4–5.5 mm. Phyllaries: (narrowly oblong-lanceolate) apices acute, abaxial faces sparsely hairy to glabrate. Corollas white, lobes densely hispid-villous. Cypselae sparsely and finely hispidulous. 2n = 34.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Aug–Oct. |habitat=Rocky slopes, mostly in pine-oak woodlands |elevation=1800–2800[–3300, Mexico] m |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina lemmonii |authority=(B. L. Robinson) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium lemmonii |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Aug–Oct. |habitat=Rocky slopes, mostly in pine-oak woodlands |elevation=1800–2800[–3300, Mexico] m |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1397.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina lemmonii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina luciae-brauniae |accepted_authority=(Fernald) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 215. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Rockhouse white snakeroot |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium luciae-brauniae |authority=Fernald |rank=species |publication_title=Rhodora |publication_place=44: 463. 1942, }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina luciae-brauniae |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina luciae-brauniae]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548 |treatment_page=page 550 }}Perennials, 30–60 cm. Stems erect, glabrous. Leaves opposite; petioles 25–70 mm; blades broadly ovate-deltate, 4–8 × 5–9 cm, (thin, delicate) bases truncate to subcordate, margins coarsely dentate, apices acute to acuminate, abaxial faces glabrous or sparsely puberulent. Heads clustered. Peduncles 1–3 mm, glabrous or sparsely puberulent. Involucres 3.5–4 mm. Phyllaries: apices acuminate, abaxial faces glabrous or sparsely puberulent. Corollas white, lobes glabrous or sparsely puberulent. Cypselae sparsely and evenly hirtellous. 2n = 34.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Aug–Oct. |habitat=Under overhanging sandstone (Pottsville formation) cliffs and ledges |elevation=400–500 m |distribution=Ky.;Tenn. |discussion=

Ageratina luciae-brauniae was treated by A. F. Clewell and J. W. Wooten (1971) as a synonym of A. altissima and regarded by them as “bizarre plants showing extreme signs of etiolation from growing under limestone ledges” (p. 134). B. E. Wofford (1976) observed that greenhouse transplants of both species maintained distinctions that provide rationale for maintaining A. luciae-brauniae at specific rank.

Ageratina luciae-brauniae is in the Center for Plant Conservation’s National Collection of Endangered Plants.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=wofford1976a |text=Wofford, B. E. 1976. The taxonomic status of Ageratina luciae-brauniae (Fern.) King & H. Robins. Phytologia 33: 369–371. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina luciae-brauniae |authority=(Fernald) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium luciae-brauniae |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Aug–Oct. |habitat=Under overhanging sandstone (Pottsville formation) cliffs and ledges |elevation=400–500 m |distribution=Ky.;Tenn. |reference=wofford1976a |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1394.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina luciae-brauniae }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina occidentalis |accepted_authority=(Hooker) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 224. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Western snakeroot |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium occidentale |authority=Hooker |rank=species |publication_title=Fl. Bor.-Amer. |publication_place=1: 305. 1833 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina occidentalis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina occidentalis]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 547, 548 |treatment_page=page 552 }}Perennials or subshrubs, 15–70 cm (caudices woody, rhizomatous). Stems (green or purple) erect or ascending, puberulent. Leaves opposite proximally, alternate on distal 1/4–1/2 of stems; petioles 5–12 mm; blades triangular to ovate, 2.5–5 × 1.7–4 cm, bases truncate to cuneate, margins serrate, apices acute, abaxial faces gland-dotted. Heads clustered. Peduncles 2–5 mm, minutely puberulent. Involucres 3–3.5(–4) mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces viscid-puberulent and/or sessile-glandular. Corollas pink, bluish, or white tinged with purple, lobes glabrous or glabrate. Cypselae sessile-glandular. 2n = 34.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Jun–)Jul–Sep. |habitat=Crevices, outcrops, rocky slopes, ridges, talus, gravelly and sandy stream bars, mixed hardwood-conifer woodlands, aspen, open and brushy vegetation |elevation=(40–50)900–2800(–3200) m |distribution=Calif.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash. |discussion=

Ageratina occidentalis is the only species of the genus in the flora area with sessile-glandular cypselae; peduncles also may be sessile-glandular. Its identity also can be confirmed among flora area species by its relatively long (5–6 mm) corollas.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina occidentalis |authority=(Hooker) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium occidentale |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering (Jun–)Jul–Sep. |habitat=Crevices, outcrops, rocky slopes, ridges, talus, gravelly and sandy stream bars, mixed hardwood-conifer woodlands, aspen, open and brushy vegetation |elevation=(40–50)900–2800(–3200) m |distribution=Calif.;Idaho;Mont.;Nev.;Oreg.;Utah;Wash. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1402.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina occidentalis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina paupercula |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 215. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Santa Rita snakeroot |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium pauperculum |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |publication_place=17: 205. 1882 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina paupercula |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina paupercula]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548, 552 |treatment_page=page 551 }}Perennials or subshrubs, to 100 cm. Stems erect, puberulent to glabrate. Leaves opposite; petioles 3–15 mm; blades narrowly to broadly lanceolate, (2–)3–7 × 0.5–1.5 cm, margins coarsely and remotely serrate, apices long-acuminate, abaxial faces sparsely pubescent. Heads clustered. Peduncles 2–6 mm, puberulent. Involucres 2.5–3 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces puberulent-hispidulous. Corollas white, lobes sparsely hispid-villous. Cypselae glabrous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Mar–May. |habitat=Rocky slopes, crevices, gravelly, sandy streambeds, pine-oak woodlands |elevation=1000–1800 m |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico. |discussion=

Ageratina paupercula is recognized by its early spring flowering, relatively small and usually narrowly lanceolate and acuminate leaves, relatively small heads in clusters, and relatively small (1.2–1.4 mm versus mostly 2–3 mm in other species), glabrous cypselae.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina paupercula |authority=(A. Gray) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium pauperculum |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Mar–May. |habitat=Rocky slopes, crevices, gravelly, sandy streambeds, pine-oak woodlands |elevation=1000–1800 m |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1399.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina paupercula }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina rothrockii |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 216. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Rothrock’s snakeroot |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium rothrockii |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=in A. Gray et al., Syn. Fl. N. Amer. |publication_place=1(2): 102. 1884 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina rothrockii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina rothrockii]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548 |treatment_page=page 550 }}Perennials, (20–)40–70(–150) cm (slender, fibrous-rooted crowns, with slender rhizomes). Stems ascending to erect, puberulent to glabrate. Leaves opposite; petioles 2–20 mm; blades (3–5-nerved) lanceolate to lanceolate-ovate, mostly 3–6 × (1.5–)2–3 cm, bases obtuse to truncate, margins serrate to crenate, apices acute to acuminate, sparsely puberulent abaxially, mostly along nerves. Heads clustered. Peduncles 5–12(–20) mm, puberulent. Involucres 5–7 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces glabrous or glabrescent, eglandular. Corollas white, lobes short-villous. Cypselae sparsely and finely strigose-hirsute. 2n = 85 [ca. 100, fide A. M. Powell on label].{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Jul–)Aug–Oct. |habitat=Rocky slopes and ledges, in oak-juniper, pine-oak, pine, aspen, and spruce-fir woodland |elevation=1700–2400 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Sonora). |discussion=

Ageratina rothrockii is similar to A. altissima, probably its western vicariant, and the two perhaps would be justifiably treated as conspecific.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina rothrockii |authority=(A. Gray) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium rothrockii |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering (Jul–)Aug–Oct. |habitat=Rocky slopes and ledges, in oak-juniper, pine-oak, pine, aspen, and spruce-fir woodland |elevation=1700–2400 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Coahuila;Durango;Sonora). |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1393.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina rothrockii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina shastensis |accepted_authority=(D. W. Taylor & Stebbins) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=45: 464. 1980 |year=1980 }} |common_names=Mt. Shasta snakeroot |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium shastense |authority=D. W. Taylor & Stebbins |rank=species |publication_title=Madroño |publication_place=25: 218, fig. 1. 1978 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina shastensis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina shastensis]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548, 553 |treatment_page=page 552 }}Perennials, 15–45 cm (bases woody, enlarged, occasionally rhizomatous). Stems erect (clustered from bases), puberulent to pubescent (often with some glandular hairs distally). Leaves opposite proximally, alternate on at least distal 1/2 of stems; petioles 4–6 mm; blades (venation raised-reticulate) orbiculate (juvenile) or deltate-ovate, 1.5–3 × 1–2 cm, (subcoriaceous) bases obtuse to truncate, margins entire or coarsely serrate to dentate, apices acute to acuminate, abaxial faces ± gland-dotted and/or stipitate-glandular. Heads mostly borne singly (each often subtended by a leaflike bract). Peduncles (0–)2–15 mm, puberulent and stipitate-glandular. Involucres 10–11 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces sparsely puberulent. Corollas white, glabrous. Cypselae hispidulous. 2n = 34.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Oct. |habitat=Cracks and crevices of nearly vertical limestone cliffs |elevation=400–1800 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Ageratina shastensis is recognized by relatively large solitary heads and coarsely serrate, subcoriaceous leaves alternate on distal parts of stems.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina shastensis |authority=(D. W. Taylor & Stebbins) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium shastense |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Oct. |habitat=Cracks and crevices of nearly vertical limestone cliffs |elevation=400–1800 m |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1980 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1403.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina shastensis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina thyrsiflora |accepted_authority=(Greene) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 227. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Congested snakeroot |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Kyrstenia thyrsiflora |authority=Greene |rank=species |publication_title=Leafl. Bot. Observ. Crit. |publication_place=1: 9. 1903 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina thyrsiflora |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina thyrsiflora]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548 |treatment_page=page 553 }}Perennials or subshrubs, 50–100 cm. Stems erect (usually forming compact ‘bushlets’), finely and evenly puberulent (hairs minute, bent). Leaves usually alternate, sometimes subopposite (densely overlapping internodes); petioles 3–20 mm; blades ovate-lanceolate to triangular, 2.5–6.5 × 1–2.5(–3) cm, bases obtuse to cuneate, margins shallowly and coarsely crenate to serrate to subentire, apices rounded-obtuse, abaxial faces hirtellous. Heads clustered (in dense, terminal aggregates). Peduncles 3–8 mm, puberulent. Involucres 2.5–3 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute to obtuse (dark orange-veined), abaxial faces. Corollas white (orange-veined), glabrous. Cypselae hispid.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Sep–Nov. |habitat=Rocky sites, oak woodland |elevation=1000–2200 m |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Durango;Jalisco;Sinaloa;Sonora). |discussion=

Ageratina thyrsiflora is known from the United States from a single collection dated 1929 from “near Nogales” in Santa Cruz County. It is recognized by its strict, unbranched or few-branched stems with alternate, densely arranged leaves, relatively small heads densely clustered in terminal aggregates, orange-veined phyllaries and corollas, and closely puberulent stems and petioles (hairs minute, sharply upwardly bent).

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina thyrsiflora |authority=(Greene) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Kyrstenia thyrsiflora |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Sep–Nov. |habitat=Rocky sites, oak woodland |elevation=1000–2200 m |distribution=Ariz.;Mexico (Chihuahua;Durango;Jalisco;Sinaloa;Sonora). |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1405.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina thyrsiflora }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratina wrightii |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) R. M. King & H. Robinson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=19: 228. 1970 |year=1970 }} |common_names=Wright’s snakeroot |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Eupatorium wrightii |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=Smithsonian Contr. Knowl. |publication_place=3(5): 87. 1852 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratina;Ageratina wrightii |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratina]]
species[[Ageratina wrightii]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 548 |treatment_page=page 552 }}Shrubs, 50–150 cm. Stems erect, puberulous. Leaves opposite proximally, alternate on distal 1/3–1/2 of stem; petioles narrowly winged, 3–5(–8) mm; blades ovate to deltate-ovate, mostly 1–2 × 0.5–1.5(–2) cm, bases truncate to cuneate or attenuate, margins entire or shallowly crenate, apices acute to blunt or obtuse, abaxial faces gland-dotted. Heads clustered. Peduncles 1–3 mm, puberulent. Involucres 3.5–4.5 mm. Phyllaries: apices acute, abaxial faces puberulent. Corollas pinkish white to pink, glabrous. Cypselae sparsely hispidulous.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering (Jul–)Aug–Oct(–Nov). |habitat=Limestone slopes, ledges, alluvium, in brushy vegetation |elevation=1300–2200 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratina wrightii |authority=(A. Gray) R. M. King & H. Robinson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Eupatorium wrightii |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering (Jul–)Aug–Oct(–Nov). |habitat=Limestone slopes, ledges, alluvium, in brushy vegetation |elevation=1300–2200 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1970 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1401.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratina |species=Ageratina wrightii }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratina]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratum |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=2: 839. 1753 |year=1753 }}, {{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. Pl. ed. |place=5, 363. 1754 |year=1754 }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratum]]
|etymology=Greek a, not, and geras, old age, apparently alluding to long-lasting nature of flowers |volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 460 |treatment_page=page 481 }}Annuals and perennials, mostly 20–120 cm. Stems often decumbent (rooting at proximal nodes), sparsely to densely branched. Leaves cauline; all or mostly opposite; petiolate; blades mostly 1-nerved, deltate to ovate, or elliptic to lanceolate, margins entire or toothed, faces glabrous or ± pilose, puberulent, or strigoso-hispid, sometimes gland-dotted. Heads discoid, in dense to open, cymiform to corymbiform arrays. Involucres campanulate, 3–6 mm. Phyllaries persistent, 30–40 in 2–3 series, usually 2-nerved, lanceolate, ± equal (often indurate, margins scarious). Receptacles conic, epaleate [paleate]. Florets 20–125; corollas white or bluish to lavender, throats ± campanulate (lengths 2 times diams.); styles: bases not enlarged, glabrous, branches ± linear to clavate (usually papillose and dilated distally). Cypselae prismatic, 4–5-ribbed, glabrous or sparsely strigoso-hispidulous; pappi persistent, of 5–6 aristate scales, or coroniform, or 0. x = 10.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=United States;Mexico;Central America;2 species widespread as adventives. |discussion=

Species ca. 40 (4 in the flora).

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=johnson1971a |text=Johnson, M. F. 1971. A monograph of the genus Ageratum L. (Compositae–Eupatorieae). Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 58: 6–88. }} }}

Nesom |authority=Linnaeus |rank=genus |parent rank=tribe |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |distribution=United States;Mexico;Central America;2 species widespread as adventives. |reference=johnson1971a |publication title=Sp. Pl. ed. |publication year=1753;1754 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1209.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratum conyzoides |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=2: 839. 1753 |year=1753 }} |common_names=Tropical whiteweed |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ageratum latifolium |authority=Cavanilles |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratum;Ageratum conyzoides |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratum]]
species[[Ageratum conyzoides]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 483 |treatment_page=page 482 }}Annuals, perennials, or sub-shrubs, 20–150 cm (fibrous-rooted). Stems erect, sparsely to densely villous. Leaf blades ovate to elliptic-oblong, 2–8 × 1–5 cm, margins toothed, abaxial faces sparsely pilose and gland-dotted. Peduncles minutely puberulent and sparsely to densely pilose, eglandular. Involucres 3–3.5 × 4–5 mm. Phyllaries oblong-lanceolate (0.8–1.2 mm wide), glabrous or sparsely pilose (margins often ciliate), eglandular, tips abruptly tapering, subulate, 0.5–1 mm. Corollas usually blue to lavender, sometimes white. Cypselae sparsely strigoso-hispidulous; pappi usually of scales 0.5–1.5(–3) mm, sometimes with tapering setae, rarely 0. 2n = 20, 40.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jul–Aug. |habitat=Disturbed sites, mostly coastal |elevation=0–20 m |distribution=Ala.;Calif.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Ky.;Md.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;South America;introduced;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;Pacific Islands (Hawaii). |introduced=true |discussion=

Ageratum conyzoides is apparently native to South America. North American plants were escapes and naturalized from cultivation.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratum conyzoides |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Ageratum latifolium |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jul–Aug. |habitat=Disturbed sites, mostly coastal |elevation=0–20 m |distribution=Ala.;Calif.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Ky.;Md.;Miss.;Mo.;N.C.;South America;introduced;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;Pacific Islands (Hawaii). |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Sp. Pl. |publication year=1753 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1212.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratum |species=Ageratum conyzoides }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratum]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratum corymbosum |accepted_authority=Zuccagni |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Cent. Observ. Bot., no. |place=85. 1806 |year=1806 }} |common_names=Flat-top whiteweed |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ageratum corymbosum var. jaliscense |authority=B. L. Robinson |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ageratum salicifolium |authority=Hemsley |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ageratum strictum |authority= |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratum;Ageratum corymbosum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratum]]
species[[Ageratum corymbosum]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 481 |treatment_page=page 482 }}Perennials or subshrubs, 30–100 cm (fibrous-rooted). Stems erect to basally decumbent, puberulent to minutely strigoso-hispid. Leaf blades ovate to rhombic-lanceolate, 3–8 × 1–3.5 cm, margins toothed, abaxial faces usually puberulent, sometimes minutely strigoso-hispid, densely gland-dotted. Peduncles finely puberulent (not pilose), eglandular. Involucres 5–6 mm. Phyllaries narrowly lanceolate (0.4–0.7 mm wide, innermost often 1–1.5 mm longer than outer), finely puberulent, eglandular, tips green or purplish, filiform. Corollas usually blue to lavender, sometimes white. Cypselae glabrous; pappi usually crowns of connate scales with erose margins or tubular portions longer than divisions, rarely with 1 or more awnlike lobes. 2n = 20, 30, 40.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jul–Oct. |habitat=Crevices, ledges, cliffs, other rocky sites in canyons, along streams, in desert grasslands, oak-agave, oak, oak-juniper, and pine-oak woodlands |elevation=(900–)1200–1900 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Mexico. |discussion=

Habitat information came mostly from collections from Sonora and Chihuahua, Mexico. Ageratum corymbosum grows in all Mexican states except for the extreme southeast. It has been included in various summaries as occurring in Texas; as noted by D. S. Correll and M. C. Johnston (1970), those records apparently were based on a collection by Charles Wright from southwestern New Mexico.

Varieties and forms of Ageratum corymbosum have been recognized (e.g., M. F. Johnson 1971; R. McVaugh 1984). McVaugh wryly noted that extremes of these intergrading infraspecific entities “can be recognized with a little imagination.” The form that reaches the United States (with ovate-lanceolate leaves) is var. jaliscense.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratum corymbosum |authority=Zuccagni |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Ageratum corymbosum var. jaliscense;Ageratum salicifolium;Ageratum strictum |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jul–Oct. |habitat=Crevices, ledges, cliffs, other rocky sites in canyons, along streams, in desert grasslands, oak-agave, oak, oak-juniper, and pine-oak woodlands |elevation=(900–)1200–1900 m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Cent. Observ. Bot., no. |publication year=1806 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1211.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratum |species=Ageratum corymbosum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratum]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratum houstonianum |accepted_authority=Miller |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Gard. Dict. ed. |place=8, Ageratum no. 2. 1768 |year=1768 }} |common_names=Bluemink |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ageratum conyzoides var. mexicanum |authority=(Sims) de Candolle |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratum;Ageratum houstonianum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratum]]
species[[Ageratum houstonianum]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 482 |treatment_page=page 483 }}Annuals, 30–80 cm (fibrous-rooted). Stems erect to decumbent, sparsely to densely pilose. Leaf blades deltate to ovate, mostly 3–8 × 2.5–4 cm, margins toothed, abaxial faces sparsely to densely pilose, not evidently gland-dotted. Peduncles viscid-puberulent, pilose, and stipitate-glandular. Involucres ca. 4 × 5–6 mm. Phyllaries narrowly lanceolate (0.6–1 mm wide), stipitate-glandular, sparsely to densely pilose, eciliate or inconspicuously ciliate, tips gradually tapering, indurate-subulate, 0.8–2 mm. Corollas usually lavender, rarely white. Cypselae sparsely strigoso-hispidulous; pappi of 5 distinct, oblong scales 2–3 mm. 2n = 20.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug. |habitat=Disturbed sites, mostly coastal |elevation=0–20 m |distribution=Ala.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Mass.;N.C.;S.C.;Tex.;Mexico;Central America;introduced;Pacific Islands (Hawaii). |introduced=true |discussion=

Ageratum houstonianum is apparently native to southeastern Mexico and Central America; the North American plants are escapes and naturalized from cultivars. M. F. Johnson (1971) observed that forma isochroum (B. L. Robinson) M. F. Johnson (type from the state of Veracruz, Mexico) sometimes may be nearly eglandular.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratum houstonianum |authority=Miller |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Ageratum conyzoides var. mexicanum |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug. |habitat=Disturbed sites, mostly coastal |elevation=0–20 m |distribution=Ala.;Conn.;Fla.;Ga.;Mass.;N.C.;S.C.;Tex.;Mexico;Central America;introduced;Pacific Islands (Hawaii). |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Gard. Dict. ed. |publication year=1768 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1213.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratum |species=Ageratum houstonianum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratum]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Ageratum maritimum |accepted_authority=Kunth |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. von Humboldt et al., Nov. Gen. Sp. |place=4(fol.): 117. 1818 |year=1818 }}, {{Treatment/Publication |place=4(qto.) 150. 1820 |year=1820 }} |common_names=Cape Sable whiteweed |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ageratum littorale |authority=A. Gray |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Ageratum littorale var. hondurense |authority=B. L. Robinson |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae;Ageratum;Ageratum maritimum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae]]
genus[[Ageratum]]
species[[Ageratum maritimum]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 481 |treatment_page=page 482 }}Annuals or perennials, 10–50 cm (semisucculent, rhizomatous, forming colonies). Stems decumbent to straggling or creeping (rooting at nodes), glabrous but for puberulous-pilose nodes. Leaf blades deltate-ovate to oblong, mostly 0.8–4 × 0.5–3 cm, (fleshy) margins toothed, faces glabrous or glabrate. Peduncles glabrous or glabrate. Involucres ca. 3 × 3–4 mm. Phyllaries elliptic-lanceolate, glabrous or glabrate, tips abruptly tapered to nearly obtuse. Corollas lavender or blue to white. Cypselae glabrous; pappi usually blunt coronas ca. 0.1 mm, rarely of separate scales.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering year round. |habitat=Beach sand and nearby thickets, coral soils, salt marshes, hammocks, roadsides |elevation=0–10 m |distribution=Fla.;Mexico (Quintana Roo);West Indies (Cuba;Hispaniola);Central America (Belize). |discussion=

Plants from Florida (Ageratum littorale, the type from Florida) are described here. Plants of the West Indies and Mexico (broadening the species concept to A. maritimum, the type from Cuba) have various elaborations of vestiture and a more conspicuous pappus–coronas with even to laciniate margins or rings of nearly separate scales mostly 0.2–1.5 mm. In addition to the distinctive relatively small, glabrous or glabrate leaves, plants of A. maritimum are characterized by heads in clusters, usually held well beyond the leaves.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Ageratum maritimum |authority=Kunth |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Ageratum littorale;Ageratum littorale var. hondurense |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering year round. |habitat=Beach sand and nearby thickets, coral soils, salt marshes, hammocks, roadsides |elevation=0–10 m |distribution=Fla.;Mexico (Quintana Roo);West Indies (Cuba;Hispaniola);Central America (Belize). |reference=None |publication title=in A. von Humboldt et al., Nov. Gen. Sp.; |publication year=1818;1820 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_1210.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Eupatorieae |genus=Ageratum |species=Ageratum maritimum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Ageratum]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Agnorhiza |accepted_authority=(Jepson) W. A. Weber |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=85: 19. 1999 |year=1999 }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Balsamorhiza sect. Agnorhiza |authority=Jepson |rank=section |publication_title=Man. Fl. Pl. Calif., |publication_place=1077. 1925 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae;Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae;Agnorhiza |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae]]
subtribe[[Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae]]
genus[[Agnorhiza]]
|etymology=Possibly Greek agnostos, unknown, and rhiza, root, alluding to the initially unknown roots; in protologue of basionym of type species, Greene stated, “Root unknown.” |volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 65, 66, 100 |treatment_page=page 104 }}Perennials, 5–60(–100) cm (taproots relatively massive; caudices sometimes branched). Stems erect and branched (mostly distally), or decumbent (and seldom branched distally). Leaves basal and cauline (basal usually scalelike on flowering stems, well-formed on non-flowering shoots); alternate; petiolate; blades (3-or 5-nerved or pinnately nerved), cordate-ovate, deltate, deltate-triangular, ovate, ovate-lanceolate, or suborbiculate, bases broadly cuneate, subcordate, or truncate, margins entire or dentate to crenate, faces glabrous or hairy (often gland-dotted). Heads radiate or discoid, borne singly (terminal) or in ± racemiform arrays. Involucres campanulate to ± hemispheric, 12–40 mm diam. Phyllaries persistent, (8–)12–26+ in 2–3+ series (subequal to unequal, outer usually surpassing inner). Receptacles flat to convex, paleate (paleae persistent, conduplicate, chartaceous). Ray florets 0 or (1–)5–21+, pistillate, fertile; corollas yellow. Disc florets 50–150+, bisexual, fertile; corollas yellow, tubes shorter than cylindric throats, lobes 5, lance-deltate (style branches stigmatic in 2, barely distinct lines, appendages filiform). Cypselae ± prismatic, 3–4-angled (faces glabrous or strigillose); pappi usually persistent, coroniform (± lacerate, sometimes with 1–4 teeth or scales), sometimes 0. x = 19.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Calif.;nw Mexico. |discussion=

Species 5 (5 in the flora).

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=weber1946a |text=Weber, W. A. 1946. A taxonomic and cytological study of the genus Wyethia, family Compositae, with notes on the related genus Balsamorhiza. Amer. Midl. Naturalist 35: 400–452. }} }}

Agnorhiza |family=Asteraceae |illustrator=John Myers |illustration copyright=Flora of North America Association |distribution=Calif.;nw Mexico. |reference=weber1946a |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1999 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_246.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae |subtribe=Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae |genus=Agnorhiza }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Agnorhiza bolanderi |accepted_authority=(A. Gray) W. A. Weber |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=85: 19. 1999 |year=1999 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Balsamorhiza bolanderi |authority=A. Gray |rank=species |publication_title=Proc. Amer. Acad. Arts |publication_place=7: 356. 1868 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Wyethia bolanderi |authority=(A. Gray) W. A. Weber |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae;Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae;Agnorhiza;Agnorhiza bolanderi |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae]]
subtribe[[Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae]]
genus[[Agnorhiza]]
species[[Agnorhiza bolanderi]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 104 |treatment_page=page 105 }}Plants (10–)15–30 cm. Stems decumbent, seldom distally branched. Cauline leaves: blades oblong, ovate, rounded-deltate, or suborbiculate, 4–12 cm, bases ± truncate or cordate, margins entire, faces glabrous (shining, finely gland-dotted, ± glutinous). Heads held among or beyond leaves. Involucres ± campanulate, 15–25(–30+) mm diam. Outer phyllaries ovate to ovate-lanceolate, 10–40+ mm (seldom surpassing ray corollas). Ray florets (7–)8–12, laminae (12–)20–30(–35) mm. Cypselae 7–9 mm, glabrous; pappi 0 or coroniform, 0.1–0.3 mm. 2n = 38.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Mar–Apr(–May). |habitat=Openings in chaparral |elevation=600–800 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Agnorhiza bolanderi is known only from the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, where it evidently grows only on serpentine soils.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Agnorhiza bolanderi |authority=(A. Gray) W. A. Weber |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Wyethia bolanderi |basionyms=Balsamorhiza bolanderi |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Mar–Apr(–May). |habitat=Openings in chaparral |elevation=600–800 m |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1999 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_247.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae |subtribe=Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae |genus=Agnorhiza |species=Agnorhiza bolanderi }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Agnorhiza]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Agnorhiza elata |accepted_authority=(H. M. Hall) W. A. Weber |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Phytologia |place=85: 19. 1999 |year=1999 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Wyethia elata |authority=H. M. Hall |rank=species |publication_title=Univ. Calif. Publ. Bot. |publication_place=4: 208. 1912, }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae;Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae;Agnorhiza;Agnorhiza elata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae]]
subtribe[[Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae]]
genus[[Agnorhiza]]
species[[Agnorhiza elata]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 104 |treatment_page=page 105 }}Plants 50–100 cm. Stems erect, usually branched distally. Cauline leaves: blades ovate-lanceolate to deltate, (8–)10–15(–20) cm, bases truncate to subcordate, margins entire or finely dentate or serrulate, faces tomentulose to pilosulous (and gland-dotted). Heads held beyond leaves. Involucres hemispheric, 25–40 mm diam. Outer phyllaries lanceolate, 20–30 mm (equaling or surpassing discs, tips often spreading to squarrose). Ray florets 10–14(–23), laminae (30–)50–60 mm. Cypselae 8–12 mm, usually glabrous, sometimes distally strigillose; pappi coroniform (lacerate, projected into scales on angles), (0.5–)1–2(–3) mm. 2n = 38.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Open pine forests |elevation=900–1200 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Agnorhiza elata is known only from foothills of the Sierra Nevada.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Agnorhiza elata |authority=(H. M. Hall) W. A. Weber |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Wyethia elata |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Open pine forests |elevation=900–1200 m |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1999 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_250.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae |subtribe=Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae |genus=Agnorhiza |species=Agnorhiza elata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Agnorhiza]]

A. Weber |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae;Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae;Agnorhiza;Agnorhiza invenusta |hierarchy_nav=

tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae]]

genus[[Agnorhiza]]
species[[Agnorhiza invenusta]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 104 |treatment_page=page 105 }}Plants 20–60(–100) cm. Stems erect, usually distally branched (densely glandular distally). Cauline leaves: blades ± deltate to ovate or ovate-lanceolate, 7–20 cm, bases broadly cuneate to truncate or shallowly cordate, margins usually entire, rarely irregularly crenate, faces piloso-hispid or hirtellous (usually gland-dotted or stipitate-glandular as well). Heads usually held beyond leaves. Involucres ± hemispheric, 20–30 mm diam. Outer phyllaries lineartriangular to lanceolate, 18–25(–30+) mm (equaling or slightly surpassing discs). Ray florets 0 or 2–3, laminae 6–10 mm. Cypselae 7–8 mm, glabrous (apices developing knoblike projections on angles); pappi 0.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Jul. |habitat=Openings in chaparral and in pine and oak forests |elevation=(600–)1100–1900(–2300) m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Agnorhiza invenusta is known only from the western foothills of the Sierra Nevada.

Weber |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Balsamorhiza invenusta;Wyethia invenusta |basionyms=Helianthus invenustus |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Jul. |habitat=Openings in chaparral and in pine and oak forests |elevation=(600–)1100–1900(–2300) m |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1999 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_249.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae |subtribe=Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae |genus=Agnorhiza |species=Agnorhiza invenusta }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Agnorhiza]]

Gray |rank=species |publication_title=in W. H. Emory, Not. Milit. Reconn., |publication_place=143. 1848 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Wyethia coriacea |authority=A. species[[Agnorhiza ovata]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 104 |treatment_page=page 105 }}Plants (5–)10–30(–45+) cm. Stems decumbent, seldom distally branched. Cauline leaves: blades broadly ovate or elliptic to suborbiculate, 7–20 cm, bases broadly cuneate to truncate or cordate, faces silky-villous to strigillose, glabrescent. Heads in axils of (and overtopped by) leaves. Involucres narrowly campanulate, 12–20(–25) mm diam. Outer phyllaries broadly linear to oblong or obovate, 12–35 mm (equaling or surpassing ray corollas). Ray florets 5–8(–9), laminae 8–18 mm. Cypselae 9–10 mm, glabrous; pappi coroniform (lacerate, projected into scales on angles), 1–1.5 mm. 2n = 38.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering May–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Grassy slopes, openings in pine forests |elevation=(900–)1300–1900 m |distribution=Calif.;Mexico (Baja California). |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Agnorhiza ovata |authority=(Torrey & Gray) W. A. Weber |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Wyethia coriacea |basionyms=Wyethia ovata |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering May–Jul(–Aug). |habitat=Grassy slopes, openings in pine forests |elevation=(900–)1300–1900 m |distribution=Calif.;Mexico (Baja California). |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1999 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_248.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae |subtribe=Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae |genus=Agnorhiza |species=Agnorhiza ovata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Agnorhiza]]

species[[Agnorhiza reticulata]]
|volume=Volume 21 |mention_page=page 104 |treatment_page=page 106 }}Plants mostly 40–70 cm. Stems erect, usually branched distally. Cauline leaves: blades (green) ovate-lanceolate to deltate, 6–15 cm, bases truncate or subcordate, margins entire or serrulate to crenate, faces sparsely hispid or scabrous (and finely gland-dotted, often vernicose). Heads held beyond or among the leaves. Involucres hemispheric, 15–30 mm diam. Outer phyllaries oblong to lanceolate or oblanceolate, 12–20+ mm (± equaling discs, tips usually spreading to squarrose). Ray florets 10–16(–21), laminae 20–25 mm. Cypselae ca. 6 mm, glabrous; pappi coroniform, 0.1–1 mm. 2n = 38.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering May–Jun. |habitat=Chaparral, oak woodlands |elevation=300–500 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Of conservation concern.

Agnorhiza reticulata is known only from foothills of the Sierra Nevada and is considered to be globally endangered.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Agnorhiza reticulata |authority=(Greene) W. A. Weber |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Wyethia reticulata |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering May–Jun. |habitat=Chaparral, oak woodlands |elevation=300–500 m |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title=Phytologia |publication year=1999 |special status=Endemic;Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V21_251.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Heliantheae |subtribe=Asteraceae (tribe Heliantheae) subtribe Ecliptinae |genus=Agnorhiza |species=Agnorhiza reticulata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Agnorhiza]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Agoseris |accepted_authority=Rafinesque |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. Ludov., |place=58. 1817 |year=1817 }} |common_names=Mountain- or false dandelion |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Cichorieae;Agoseris |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Cichorieae]]
genus[[Agoseris]]
|etymology=Greek agos, leader, and seris, chicory; allusion unclear |volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 215, 217, 322, 324, 326, 333, 334, 335 |treatment_page=page 323 }}Dioecious. Plants 3–14 cm (bases woody). Stolons none. Basal leaves absent at flowering. Cauline leaves linear-lanceolate to cuneate-oblanceolate, 11–35 × 2–6 imm, acute, not flagged (apices acute), faces gray-pubescent. Heads 3–25 in corymbiform to paniculiform arrays. Involucres: staminate 6–8 mm; pistillate 6–8 mm. Phyllaries distally red to pink, light brown, or white. Corollas: staminate 3–4.5 mm; pistillate 5–6 mm. Cypselae 2–2.5 mm, pubescent and papillate; pappi: staminate 6–7 mm (capillary); pistillate 6–7 mm. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=North America;South America. |discussion=

Species 11 (10, including 1 hybrid, in the flora).

Agoseris consists of widespread species that individually exhibit great morphologic plasticity. Difficulty in correctly identifying individual specimens is compounded by traits that may vary from region to region, the perpetuation of misleading or inaccurate traits in the literature, and the presence of intermediates. Correct identification of Agoseris specimens can be assisted by knowing that species may exhibit variable traits (e.g., pubescence, corolla color, cypsela morphology), some species have leaf lobing variable on single plants (e.g., outermost entire versus inner lobed), and intermediate specimens may occur with any sympatric taxa. Hybridization among members of the genus is common, especially among polyploid taxa, and some hybrid populations appear to be persistent. Autogamy has been demonstrated in some species (K. L. Chambers 1963) and is suspected in others. It appears to be correlated with a reduction in corolla and anther size. Autogamous populations or taxa often exhibit seemingly unique features that appear localized. Attempts at naming these variant populations or regional phases have resulted in a large number of synonyms.

Agoseris has a New World, amphitropical distribution. All of the species are restricted to North America except A. coronopifolia (D’Urville) K. L. Chambers, which is found in temperate regions of southern South America. The South American disjunction appears to be the result of long-distance dispersal from North America (K. L. Chambers 1963).

Agoseris appears to be most closely related to Nothocalaïs.

Cryptopleura Nuttall, referable here, is a rejected name.

In keys and descriptions, lengths of cypselae include beaks.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=baird1996a |text=Baird, G. I. 1996. The Systematics of Agoseris (Asteraceae: Lactuceae). Ph.D. dissertation. University of Texas. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=chambers1963b |text=Chambers, K. L. 1963. Amphitropical species pairs in Microseris and Agoseris (Compositae: Cichorieae). Quart. Rev. Biol. 38: 124–140. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=jones1954a |text=Jones, Q. 1954. Monograph of Agoseris, Tribe Cichorieae. Ph.D. dissertation. Harvard University. }} }}

revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Agoseris apargioides |accepted_authority=(Lessing) Greene |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Pittonia |place=2: 177. 1891 |year=1891 }} |common_names=Seaside agoseris |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Troximon apargioides |authority=Lessing |rank=species |publication_title=Linnaea |publication_place=6: 501. 1831 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Cichorieae;Agoseris;Agoseris apargioides |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Cichorieae]]
genus[[Agoseris]]
species[[Agoseris apargioides]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 325, 330, 332, 333 |treatment_page=page 331 }}Stems 0 or 1–5+ (becoming buried by drifting sand and appearing pseudorhizomatous). Leaves usually reclining to decumbent, sometimes erect; blades mostly oblanceolate to spatulate, sometimes nearly linear, 3–15 cm, margins usually dentate to lobed or pinnatifid, rarely entire, lobes 3–5(–7) pairs, filiform to spatulate, spreading to antrorse, lobules mostly 0, faces glabrous or densely hairy. Peduncles ± elongating after flowering, 7–45 cm in fruit, glabrous or glabrate to hairy, often villous basally, sometimes villous to tomentose apically, sometimes stipitate-glandular. Involucres obconic to hemispheric, 1.5–2.5 cm in fruit. Phyllaries imbricate (sometimes subequal) in 2–3 series, green or medially rosy purple, often spotted and/or with purple-black midstripes, margins ciliate to tomentose, faces usually ± villous, sometimes glabrous, sometimes stipitate-glandular; outer mostly spreading, adaxially usually ± tomentose, rarely glabrous; inner erect, elongating after flowering. Receptacles epaleate. Florets 25–200; corollas yellow, tubes 2–5.5 mm, ligules 3–16 × 1–3 mm; anthers 1.5–4.5 mm. Cypselae 5–12 mm; bodies fusiform to obconic, 3–5 mm, beaks (1–)3–8 mm, lengths mostly 1–2 times bodies; pappus bristles in 2–3 series, 4–9 mm. 2n = 36.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Calif.;Oreg.;Wash. |discussion=

Varieties 3 (3 in the flora).

A misinterpretation of the type description of Agoseris apargioides resulted in its confusion with A. hirsuta during the latter half of the twentieth century; the two species are not conspecific. Agoseris apargioides (in the strict sense) here includes what most authors of recent floras have called A. apargioides subsp. maritima and/or var. eastwoodiae. It occurs on coastal dunes along the Pacific coast from central California to Washington. A unique feature of A. apargioides is that its stems become progressively buried by drifting sand, leaving a terminal rosette of leaves exposed, the plants thus appearing pseudorhizomatous.

Agoseris apargioides is part of a close alliance that includes A. heterophylla, A. hirsuta, and A. coronopifolia from South America. Exact relationships within this group are not clear. Putative hybrids between A. apargioides and A. heterophylla var. cryptopleura, A. hirsuta, and A. grandiflora var. grandiflora have been identified.

|tables= |references= }}

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Agoseris apargioides var. apargioides |accepted_authority= |publications= |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Agoseris humilis |authority=(Bentham) Kuntze |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Asteraceae;Asteraceae tribe Cichorieae;Agoseris;Agoseris apargioides;Agoseris apargioides var. apargioides |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Asteraceae]]
tribe[[Asteraceae tribe Cichorieae]]
genus[[Agoseris]]
species[[Agoseris apargioides]]
variety[[Agoseris apargioides var. apargioides]]
|volume=Volume 19 |mention_page=page 332 |treatment_page=page 331 }}Leaves mostly reclining to prostrate; blades usually linear to oblanceolate, rarely spatulate, 3–10(–15) cm × 1–15(–24) mm, margins toothed to lobed, sometimes laciniately pinnatifid or entire, lobes filiform to oblanceolate, faces glabrous or sparsely villous. Phyllaries lanceolate to obovate or oblong, margins ciliate to tomentose, faces glabrous or villous (hairs translucent, whitish or yellowish, sometimes purple-septate), ± stipitate-glandular. Corollas surpassing phyllaries at flowering, ligules 8–16 mm; anthers 3.5–4.5 mm. Cypselae ± dimorphic, whitish or purplish, ribs ridged to subalate, straight or slightly undulate, often diminishing proximally, glabrous or scabrous. 2n = 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Apr–May (year-round). |habitat=Coastal dunes |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Variety apargioides occurs from San Francisco southward to Point Sur.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Agoseris apargioides var. apargioides |authority= |rank=variety |parent rank=species |synonyms=Agoseris humilis |basionyms= |family=Asteraceae |phenology=Flowering Apr–May (year-round). |habitat=Coastal dunes |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Calif. |reference=None |publication title= |publication year= |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V19-20-21/V19_507.xml |tribe=Asteraceae tribe Cichorieae |genus=Agoseris |species=Agoseris apargioides |variety=Agoseris apargioides var. apargioides }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Agoseris apargioides]]

Phyllaries ovate to obovate, margins mostly densely tomentose, densely villous to tomentose (hairs translucent, mostly yellow), ± stipitate-glandular. Corollas surpassing phyllaries at flowering, 8–16 mm; anthers 3.5–4.5 mm. Cypselae ± dimorphic, whitish or purplish, ribs ridged to subalate, straight, often diminishing proximally, glabrous or scabrous. 2n = 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering April–May (year-round). |habitat=Coastal dunes and beach heads |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=Calif. |discussion=

Variety eastwoodiae occurs from Point Reyes north to about Point Arena.

Phyllaries lanceolate to oblanceolate, margins glabrous or ciliate, faces glabrous or villous (hairs opaque, mostly whitish), mostly eglandular. Corollas ± equal to phyllaries at flowering, ligules 3–6 mm; anthers 1.5–2.5 mm. Cypselae ± monomorphic, whitish, not purplish, ribs ± ridged, straight, ± uniform. 2n = 36.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jul–Aug. |habitat=Coastal dunes, sand hills, and beach heads |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=Calif.;Oreg.;Wash. |discussion=

Variety maritima occurs from Humboldt Bay, California, to Neah Bay, Washington.
