{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla glabra |accepted_authority=Neygenfind |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Ench. Bot., |place=67. 1821 |year=1821 }} |common_names=Smooth lady's mantle;alchémille glabre |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alchemilla alpestris |authority=(F. W. Schmidt) Opiz |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. vulgaris var. alpestris |authority=F. W. Schmidt |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. vulgaris var. grandis |authority=Blytt |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla glabra |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla glabra]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 304 |treatment_page=page 305 }}Plants medium-sized to occasionally very large, yellowish grass green to dark green, often reddish brown on exposed parts of stems and petioles. Stems glabrous or appressed-hairy proximally, glabrous distally. Leaves: stipules translucent, usually suffused with red proximally, translucent to pale green distally, lobes pale green; petiole glabrous or sparsely to densely appressed-hairy; blade reniform-orbiculate, 7–9(–11)-lobed, margins flat or slightly undulate, basal sinuses narrow or wide, middle lobes as long as to longer than their half-widths, rounded to triangular-ovate; incisions absent; teeth ± connivent, slightly concave near apex, strongly asymmetric, apex subacute or obtuse, abaxial surface with nerves hairy throughout or in distal 1/2 only, internerve regions glabrous, adaxial glabrous or slightly hairy near margins, rarely (late-season leaves) hairy on folds. Inflorescences: primary branches glabrous. Pedicels glabrous. Flowers: epicalyx bractlet lengths 0.5 times sepals (narrower); hypanthium glabrous. Achenes exserted from discs.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jul–Aug. |habitat=Meadows |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=N.B.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);Que.;Alaska;Europe. |introduced=true |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla glabra |authority=Neygenfind |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Alchemilla alpestris;A. vulgaris var. alpestris;A. vulgaris var. grandis |basionyms= |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering Jul–Aug. |habitat=Meadows |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=N.B.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);Que.;Alaska;Europe. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Ench. Bot., |publication year=1821 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V9/V9_491.xml |subfamily=Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla glabra }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla glaucescens |accepted_authority=Wallroth |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Linnaea |place=14: 134. 1840 |year=1840 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla glaucescens |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla glaucescens]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 303, 304 |treatment_page=page 308 }}Plants small, gray-green, to 20 cm. Stems densely ascending-spreading-hairy, sometimes sericeous. Leaves: stipules translucent, colorless, sometimes flushed pale wine red proximally, green distally, lobes green; blade orbiculate, rather shallowly 7–9-lobed, margins flat or slightly undulate, basal sinuses closed, middle lobes rounded, as long as to slightly longer than their half-widths; incisions usually absent or relatively short, sometimes relatively long; teeth slightly connivent, slightly asymmetric, apex subacute or almost digitate, surfaces densely hairy. Inflorescences: primary branches sericeous; peduncles sericeous. Pedicels sericeous. Flowers: epicalyx bractlet lengths 0.5 times as sepals (narrower); hypanthium sericeous. Achenes not or exserted to 1/20 from discs.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug. |habitat=Waste ground |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=Que.;Europe. |introduced=true |discussion=

In the flora area, Alchemilla glaucescens is known only from Grosse-Ile in the St. Lawrence River.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla glaucescens |authority=Wallroth |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Aug. |habitat=Waste ground |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=Que.;Europe. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Linnaea |publication year=1840 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V9/V9_501.xml |subfamily=Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla glaucescens }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla glomerulans |accepted_authority=Buser |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Herb. Boissier |place=1(app. 2): 30. 1893 |year=1893 }} |common_names=Clustered lady's mantle;alchémille à glomérules |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alchemilla obtusa |authority=Buser |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. obtusa var. comosa |authority=Brenner |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. pseudomicans |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. vulgaris var. comosa |authority=(Brenner) Fernald & Wiegand |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla glomerulans |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla glomerulans]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 302, 304, 306 |treatment_page=page 305 }}Plants medium-sized, grass green or glaucous, often becoming reddish orange when young changing to dark brownish especially on margins of leaves and flowers (young flowers are yellowish), often coarse, 30–40 cm. Stems appressed-hairy throughout (hairs becoming looser and ± ascending distally). Leaves: stipules translucent to pale green, appearing brownish upon drying; petiole thickly, usually densely appressed-hairy throughout, rarely glabrous or sparsely hairy (on spring leaves); blade reniform to orbiculate, 7–9-lobed, margins undulate, basal sinuses narrow, middle lobes equal to longer than their half-widths; incisions absent; teeth: sometimes proximal sides at least slightly connivent, slightly concave near apex, slightly asymmetric, apex subobtuse to acute, abaxial surface with nerves hairy throughout, internerve regions ± hairy throughout, adaxial light to grass green, sometimes glaucous, margins and folds usually turning reddish orange, sparsely to densely appressed-hairy throughout or only on folds. Inflorescences: primary branches densely appressed- to ascending-hairy; peduncles appressed- to ascending-hairy or glabrous. Pedicels mostly glabrous or some of the proximal hairy. Flowers: epicalyx bractlet lengths 0.5 times to almost equal to sepals (narrower); hypanthium glabrous or sparsely appressed-hairy (on proximalmost flowers). Achenes not exserted.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late Jun–Sep. |habitat=Moist herb slopes, willow scrub |elevation=0–500 m |distribution=Greenland;Nfld. and Labr. (Labr.);Que.;Europe. |discussion=

In contrast to Alchemilla wichurae, A. glomerulans occurs throughout the southern (unglaciated) portion of Greenland.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla glomerulans |authority=Buser |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Alchemilla obtusa;A. obtusa var. comosa;A. pseudomicans;A. vulgaris var. comosa |basionyms= |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering late Jun–Sep. |habitat=Moist herb slopes, willow scrub |elevation=0–500 m |distribution=Greenland;Nfld. and Labr. (Labr.);Que.;Europe. |reference=None |publication title=Bull. Herb. Boissier |publication year=1893 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V9/V9_493.xml |subfamily=Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla glomerulans }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla micans |accepted_authority=Buser |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Herb. Boissier |place=1(app. 2): 28. 1893 |year=1893 }} |common_names=Gleaming lady’s mantle |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla micans |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla micans]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 304 |treatment_page=page 308 }}Plants medium-sized, dark green, often somewhat sericeous (abaxial surface of leaves), sometimes reddish brown, especially on exposed distal part of stems and inflorescences, to 50 cm. Stems usually densely spreading- to slightly ascending-hairy, usually glabrous in distal 1/2. Leaves: stipules translucent, strongly wine red-tinged proximally, lobes pale green, sometimes suffused wine red; petiole densely spreading- or slightly ascending-hairy (especially in distal 1/3); blade usually reniform to orbiculate, 7–9-lobed, margins flat, sometimes slightly undulate, basal sinuses relatively wide or narrow, basal lobes not overlapping, middle lobes rounded, as long as to longer than their half-widths, to as long as wide and with straight sides; incisions usually absent or relatively short; teeth usually slightly connivent, almost symmetric to ± asymmetric, apex acute, abaxial surface with nerves hairy throughout, internerve regions uniformly or irregularly hairy, adaxial densely appressed-hairy throughout. Inflorescences: primary branches often sparsely, sometimes densely, ascending-hairy; peduncles glabrous or hairy. Pedicels glabrous or some of the proximal hairy. Flowers dark green, often becoming reddish; epicalyx bractlet lengths 0.5+ times sepals (narrower); hypanthium attenuate at base, usually glabrous, rarely sparsely hairy (in proximal flowers). Achenes not exserted.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late May–Sep. |habitat=Meadows, moist sand |elevation=0–400 m |distribution=Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.S.;Que.;Maine;N.Y.;Europe. |introduced=true |discussion=

Alchemilla micans has been widely known as A. gracilis Opiz; the type of that name is referable to A. monticola, a species that the original description also fits better.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla micans |authority=Buser |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering late May–Sep. |habitat=Meadows, moist sand |elevation=0–400 m |distribution=Nfld. and Labr. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla micans }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla mollis |accepted_authority=(Buser) Rothmaler |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. |place=33: 347. 1934 |year=1934 }} |common_names=Garden lady’s mantle |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Alchemilla acutiloba var. mollis |authority=Buser |rank=variety |publication_title=Bull. Herb. Boissier |publication_place=4: 759. 1896 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla mollis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla mollis]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 303, 304 |treatment_page=page 309 }}Plants large to very large, yellowish green, to 80 cm, often very robust, densely hairy, hairs patent, soft. Stems densely spreading-hairy (to inflorescences). Leaves: stipules translucent, usually pale pink proximally, lobes turning brownish; blade orbiculate or reniform-orbiculate, 9–11-lobed, margins flat or slightly undulate, basal sinuses narrow to almost closed, basal lobes sometimes overlapping, middle lobes with lateral sides convex or slightly concave at base, shorter than to as long as their half-widths; incisions absent; teeth slightly connivent or not, ± symmetric, apex acute or subacute, surfaces densely hairy throughout. Inflorescences: primary branches densely hairy; peduncles pubescent or almost glabrous. Pedicels glabrous. Flowers: epicalyx bractlet lengths 1 times sepals (as wide), often with blunt teeth, glabrous; epicalyx bractlets and sepals patent after flowering, giving appearance of an 8-point star; hypanthium usually densely, occasionally sparsely, hairy (in proximal 1/2). Achenes exserted from discs (distinctly longer than hypanthia).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late Jul–Sep. |habitat=Densely vegetated lake shores |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=B.C.;Ont.;Europe (e Carpathians);w Asia (Caucasus;Turkey). |introduced=true |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla mollis |authority=(Buser) Rothmaler |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Alchemilla acutiloba var. mollis |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering late Jul–Sep. |habitat=Densely vegetated lake shores |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=B.C.;Ont.;Europe (e Carpathians);w Asia (Caucasus;Turkey). |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. |publication year=1934 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V9/V9_503.xml |subfamily=Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla mollis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla monticola |accepted_authority=Opiz |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in F. Berchtold et al., Oekon.-techn. Fl. Böhm. |place=2(1): 13. 1838 |year=1838 }} |common_names=Mountain alchemilla;alchémille des montagnes |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alchemilla pastoralis |authority=Buser |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. vulgaris var. pastoralis |authority=(Buser) B. Boivin |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla monticola |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla monticola]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 304 |treatment_page=page 308 }}Plants medium-sized, grass green, young inflorescences yellowish, often becoming reddish brown, 25–30(–40) cm, often robust. Stems densely spreading-hairy in distal 1/2. Leaves: stipules translucent to pale green proximally, apex green; blade reniform or reniform-orbiculate, rather shallowly 7–9-lobed, margins flat or slightly undulate, basal sinuses wide or narrow, basal lobes not overlapping, middle lobes rounded, equal to longer than their half-width; incisions usually relatively short, sometimes absent or relatively long; teeth usually slightly connivent, mostly slightly asymmetric but a few strongly so, apex acute to subobtuse, surfaces densely pubescent throughout, adaxial gray green to dark green. Inflorescences: primary branches densely hairy; peduncles sparsely hairy or glabrous. Pedicels glabrous or some of the proximal hairy. Flowers green, often becoming reddish; epicalyx bractlet lengths at least 0.5 times sepals (not longer, always narrower); hypanthium rounded at base, usually sparsely to densely spreading-hairy, rarely glabrous. Achenes exserted 1/5 from discs.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late May–Sep. |habitat=Meadows, lawns, ditches, under trees |elevation=0–3000 m |distribution=B.C.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Conn.;Maine;Mass.;Mont.;N.H.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;Vt.;Wis.;Europe. |introduced=true |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla monticola |authority=Opiz |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Alchemilla pastoralis;A. vulgaris var. pastoralis |basionyms= |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering late May–Sep. |habitat=Meadows, lawns, ditches, under trees |elevation=0–3000 m |distribution=B.C.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.S.;Ont.;Que.;Conn.;Maine;Mass.;Mont.;N.H.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;Vt.;Wis.;Europe. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=in F. Berchtold et al., Oekon.-techn. Fl. Böhm. |publication year=1838 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V9/V9_500.xml |subfamily=Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla monticola }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla subcrenata |accepted_authority=Buser |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Scrinia Fl. Select. |place=12: 285. 1893 |year=1893 }} |common_names=Round-toothed lady’s mantle;alchémille subcrénelée |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla subcrenata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla subcrenata]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 304 |treatment_page=page 306 }}Plants medium-sized, sometimes larger, yellowish green to dark green, often reddish brown especially on stems, petioles, and inflorescence branches, to 50 cm. Stems densely spreading- to slightly reflexed-pubescent or only sparsely so in distal 1/2. Leaves: stipules translucent, sometimes wine red-tinged proximally, lobes green; petiole sparsely to densely spreading- to reflexed-hairy; blade reniform to orbiculate, 7–9-lobed, margins strongly plicate to undulate, basal sinuses closed, basal lobes overlapping (in plants from spring-flooded habitats, only cauline leaves with wide sinus may persist), middle lobes usually longer than their half-widths, as long as wide, longer than wide (with ± straight sides); incisions absent; teeth: proximal sides connivent or slightly so, sometimes slightly concave near apex, slightly to strongly asymmetric, apex subobtuse to obtuse, abaxial surface grass green to dark green, nerves hairy throughout, internerve regions irregularly or uniformly hairy, adaxial densely spreading-hairy throughout or only on margins and folds. Inflorescences: primary branches sparsely to densely hairy; peduncles glabrous or sparsely hairy. Pedicels glabrous. Flowers green, often becoming reddish brown; epicalyx bractlet lengths 0.5 times sepals (narrower); hypanthium glabrous. Achenes exserted to 1/3 from discs.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jun–Sep. |habitat=Moist grasslands, flood plains |elevation=0–1400 m |distribution=B.C.;Que.;Mont.;Europe. |introduced=true |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla subcrenata |authority=Buser |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering Jun–Sep. |habitat=Moist grasslands, flood plains |elevation=0–1400 m |distribution=B.C.;Que.;Mont.;Europe. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Scrinia Fl. Select. |publication year=1893 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V9/V9_495.xml |subfamily=Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla subcrenata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla venosa |accepted_authority=Juzepczuk |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in A. A. Grossheim, Fl. Kavkaza |place=4: 328. 1934 |year=1934 }} |common_names=Veined lady’s mantle |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla venosa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla venosa]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 303, 304 |treatment_page=page 309 }}Plants medium-sized, darkish green, sometimes reddish tinged, to 40 cm. Stems ± appressed-hairy. Leaves: stipules green or slightly purplish tinged, turning brown; blade orbiculate, 7–9-lobed, margins undulate, basal sinuses appearing closed, basal lobes overlapping, middle lobes rounded, as long as or longer than their half-widths; incisions relatively short to long; teeth ± connivent, slightly asymmetric, apex acute, abaxial surface with nerves hairy throughout, internerve regions glabrous or densely hairy throughout, adaxial glabrous or hairy only on folds. Inflorescences: primary branches densely hairy; peduncles hairy or glabrous. Pedicels glabrous. Flowers: epicalyx bractlet lengths equal to slightly longer than sepals (usually almost as wide); epicalyx segments and sepals patent after flowering, giving appearance of an 8-point star; hypanthium usually shorter than sepals, glabrous. Achenes exserted from discs (distinctly longer than hypanthia).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late Jun–Aug. |habitat=Grasslands, often near sea shores |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=N.B.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.S.;sw Asia (Caucasus;e Turkey). |introduced=true |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla venosa |authority=Juzepczuk |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering late Jun–Aug. |habitat=Grasslands, often near sea shores |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=N.B.;Nfld. and Labr. (Nfld.);N.S.;sw Asia (Caucasus;e Turkey). |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=in A. A. Grossheim, Fl. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla wichurae |accepted_authority=(Buser) Stefánsson |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. Íslands, |place=135. 1901 |year=1901 }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Alchemilla connivens |authority=Buser [unranked] wichurae Buser |rank=species |publication_title=Bull. Herb. Boissier |publication_place=2: 110. 1894 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=A. vulgaris var. wichurae |authority=(Buser) B. Boivin |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla wichurae |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla wichurae]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 303, 304, 306 |treatment_page=page 305 }}Plants medium-sized, often purple on stems, petioles, and margins of leaves and stem leaves, usually thin and delicate, 20–30 cm. Stems sparsely appressed-hairy throughout or glabrous in distal 1/2. Leaves: stipules translucent, colorless, usually flushed pale wine red proximally, apex pale green, sometimes with pale wine red margins and veins; blade reniform-orbiculate, 7–9-lobed, margins flat, basal sinuses narrow or closed, middle lobes as long as and rounded to longer than their half-widths; incisions long or short, 2–5 mm; teeth usually connivent, symmetric to slightly asymmetric, apex acute, abaxial surface with nerves hairy throughout or in distal 1/2 only, internerve regions usually glabrous (except sometimes on 2 basal lobes), adaxial glabrous or slightly hairy at margin. Inflorescences: primary branches glabrous. Pedicels glabrous. Flowers: epicalyx bractlet lengths 0.5 times to almost equal to sepals (always narrower); hypanthium glabrous. Achenes not exserted.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Jul. |habitat=Moist herb slopes |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Greenland;Europe. |discussion=

In the flora area, Alchemilla wichurae is restricted to a small area on the southeast coast of Greenland, mostly (or all) in Angmagssalik district.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla wichurae |authority=(Buser) Stefánsson |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=A. vulgaris var. wichurae |basionyms=Alchemilla connivens |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering Jul. |habitat=Moist herb slopes |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Greenland;Europe. |reference=None |publication title=Fl. Íslands, |publication year=1901 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V9/V9_492.xml |subfamily=Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla wichurae }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alchemilla xanthochlora |accepted_authority=Rothmaler |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. |place=42: 167. 1937 |year=1937 }} |common_names=Yellow-green lady’s mantle |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Rosaceae;Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae;Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae;Alchemilla;Alchemilla xanthochlora |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Rosaceae]]
subfamily[[Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae]]
tribe[[Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae]]
genus[[Alchemilla]]
species[[Alchemilla xanthochlora]]
|volume=Volume 9 |mention_page=page 304 |treatment_page=page 306 }}Plants large, yellowish green to green, rarely with reddish orange leaf margins, robust, compact often with rather rigid stems, 40–60 cm. Stems usually densely spreading-hairy, sometimes sparsely in distal 1/2. Leaves: stipules translucent, colorless proximally, lobes green, quickly turning brownish; petiole thickly, densely pubescent (hairs patent or, when not fully developed, slightly ascending); blade reniform to orbiculate, 7–11-lobed, margins flat or slightly undulate, basal sinuses wide, basal lobes not overlapping, middle lobes equal to longer than their half-widths and rounded, or as long as wide and straight-sided; incisions usually absent, sometimes relatively short; teeth sometimes proximal sides at least slightly connivent, side slightly concave near apex, usually slightly, sometimes markedly, asymmetric, apex acute to subobtuse, abaxial surface with nerves hairy throughout, internerve regions uniformly or irregularly hairy throughout, adaxial yellowish to light green, usually glabrous, rarely sparsely hairy on teeth, margins, and folds or on some folds only. Inflorescences: primary branches densely hairy; peduncles sparsely hairy or glabrous. Pedicels glabrous or some of the proximal rarely sparsely hairy. Flowers: epicalyx bractlet lengths 0.5 times to almost equal to sepals (narrower); hypanthium usually glabrous or sparsely hairy (on proximalmost flowers). Achenes exserted 1/3 from discs.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late May–Sep. |habitat=Moist meadows, herb slopes, willow scrub, ditches, lawns |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=N.B.;N.S.;Que.;Europe. |introduced=true |discussion=

Alchemilla xanthochlora was recognized by P. A. Rydberg (1908–1918) and M. L. Fernald (1950) as A. pratensis attributed to F. W. Schmidt, as typical A. vulgaris Linnaeus by M. L. Fernald and K. M. Wiegand (1912), and as A. vulgaris var. vulgaris by B. Boivin (1966b). Actually, Schmidt published a varietal name [A. vulgaris var. pratensis F. W. Schmidt, A. pratensis (F. W. Schmidt) Opiz], which does not apply to this species nor does A. vulgaris.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alchemilla xanthochlora |authority=Rothmaler |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Rosaceae |phenology=Flowering late May–Sep. |habitat=Moist meadows, herb slopes, willow scrub, ditches, lawns |elevation=0–50 m |distribution=N.B.;N.S.;Que.;Europe. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Repert. Spec. Nov. Regni Veg. |publication year=1937 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V9/V9_494.xml |subfamily=Rosaceae subfam. Rosoideae |tribe=Rosaceae tribe Potentilleae |genus=Alchemilla |species=Alchemilla xanthochlora }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alchemilla]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aletris |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 319. 1753 |year=1753 }}, {{Treatment/Publication |title=Gen. Pl. ed. |place=5, 149. 1754 |year=1754 }} |common_names=Colic-root;stargrass |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Liliaceae;Aletris |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Liliaceae]]
genus[[Aletris]]
|etymology=Greek aletris, a female slave who ground corn, alluding to the mealy texture of the perianths |volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 51, 55, 56, 57, 65, 67 |treatment_page=page 64 }}Herbs, perennial, scapose, rhizomatous. Leaves in dense basal rosettes, clasping erect branches; blade narrowly linear to lanceolate, oblanceolate, linear-elliptic, or elliptic, flat, leathery, distal margins fused to form subulate tips. Scape 2–10 dm. Inflorescences racemose. Flowers each subtended by 2 subulate, unequal bracts, short-pedicellate; perianth white, yellow, or golden orange, cylindrical, campanulate, or obovoid, abaxial surfaces rough; tepals 6, connate basally; stamens 6, included; filaments adnate to perianth; anthers oblong-lanceolate, longer than filaments; ovary half inferior with proximal portions of perianth adnate at maturity; style 3-branched at apex. Fruits capsular, 3-locular, beaked. Seeds amber, deeply sulcate, ellipsoid to ovoid, 0.5–0.8 mm, lustrous.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=North America;West Indies (Bahamas);eastern Asia. |discussion=

Species ca. 25 (5 in the flora).

Some species of Aletris (e.g., A. lutea and A. obovata) are quickly eliminated unless habitats are occasionally burned or otherwise kept clear of undergrowth.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=sullivan1973a |text=Sullivan, V. I. 1973. Biosystematics of Aletris lutea Small, Aletris obovata Nash and natural hybrids. Brittonia 25: 294–303. }} }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Perianth usually wholly yellow to golden yellow, rarely white. |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Perianth white to creamy white, lobes sometimes tipped with orange or pinkish orange. |[[#key-0-3| > 3]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Perianth cylindrical, 9–12 mm, more than 2.5 times as long as broad, lobes spreading. |[[Aletris lutea|Aletris lutea]] |-id=key-0-2 |2 |Perianth campanulate, 6–7 mm, 2 times or less as long as broad, lobes erect. |[[Aletris aurea|Aletris aurea]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Perianth campanulate or obovoid, lobes turned slightly inward. |[[Aletris obovata|Aletris obovata]] |-id=key-0-3 |3 |Perianth cylindrical, lobes spreading. |[[#key-0-4| > 4]] |-id=key-0-4 |4 |Leaves dull grayish green, 0.6–1 cm wide; beaks of fruits gradually tapering from body to tip. |[[Aletris bracteata|Aletris bracteata]] |-id=key-0-4 |4 |Leaves bright yellowish green, 0.5–2.6 cm wide; beaks of fruits abruptly narrowed distally. |[[Aletris farinosa|Aletris farinosa]] |}

Sullivan |authority=Linnaeus |rank=genus |parent rank=family |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Liliaceae |illustrator=Barbara Alongi |illustration copyright=Flora of North America Association |distribution=North America;West Indies (Bahamas);eastern Asia. |reference=sullivan1973a |publication title=Sp. Pl. ed. |publication year=1753;1754 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_37.xml |genus=Aletris }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Liliaceae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aletris aurea |accepted_authority=Walter |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Fl. Carol., |place=121. 1788 |year=1788 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Liliaceae;Aletris;Aletris aurea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Liliaceae]]
genus[[Aletris]]
species[[Aletris aurea]]
|volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 65 |treatment_page=page 66 }}Leaves 2–8 × 1–2 cm; blade bright green, elliptic to lanceolate. Scape 2–8 dm. Flowers: perianth golden yellow, campanulate, 6–7 mm, 2 times or less as long as broad, lobes erect. Fruits: beaks gradually narrowed distally. 2n = 26.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Dry to wet pine flatwoods, savannas, and bogs |elevation=0–100+ m |distribution=Ala.;Ark.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Md.;Miss.;N.C.;Okla.;S.C.;Tex.;Va. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aletris aurea |authority=Walter |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Liliaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Dry to wet pine flatwoods, savannas, and bogs |elevation=0–100+ m |distribution=Ala.;Ark.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Md.;Miss.;N.C.;Okla.;S.C.;Tex.;Va. |reference=None |publication title=Fl. Carol., |publication year=1788 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_42.xml |genus=Aletris |species=Aletris aurea }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aletris]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aletris bracteata |accepted_authority=Northrop |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |place=12: 27, plate 1. 1902 |year=1902 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=C |label=Conservation concern }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Liliaceae;Aletris;Aletris bracteata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Liliaceae]]
genus[[Aletris]]
species[[Aletris bracteata]]
|volume=Volume 26 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 65 }}Leaves 5–17 × 0.6–1 cm; blade dull grayish green, linear-lanceolate. Scape 5–6 dm. Flowers: perianth white, cylindrical, 6–8 mm, lobes spreading. Fruits: beaks gradually tapering distally.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering year round. |habitat=Everglades, pinelands |elevation=0 m |distribution=Fla.;West Indies (Bahamas: Abaco and Andros Islands). |discussion=

of conservation concern

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aletris bracteata |authority=Northrop |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Liliaceae |phenology=Flowering year round. |habitat=Everglades, pinelands |elevation=0 m |distribution=Fla.;West Indies (Bahamas: Abaco and Andros Islands). |reference=None |publication title=Mem. Torrey Bot. Club |publication year=1902 |special status=Conservation concern |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_38.xml |genus=Aletris |species=Aletris bracteata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aletris]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aletris farinosa |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 319. 1753 |year=1753 }} |common_names=Unicorn root;white stargrass |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Liliaceae;Aletris;Aletris farinosa |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Liliaceae]]
genus[[Aletris]]
species[[Aletris farinosa]]
|volume=Volume 26 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 65 }}Leaves 4–20 × 0.5–2.6 cm; blade bright yellowish green, linear-lanceolate. Scape 4–10 dm. Flowers: perianth white to creamy white, cylindrical, 7–10 mm, lobes spreading. Fruits: beaks abruptly narrowed distally.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Open sites of various habitats, moist bogs, dry to mesic prairies, and dry, upland woods and thickets |elevation=0–2000+ m |distribution=Ont.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;D.C.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Miss.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aletris farinosa |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Liliaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Open sites of various habitats, moist bogs, dry to mesic prairies, and dry, upland woods and thickets |elevation=0–2000+ m |distribution=Ont.;Ala.;Ark.;Conn.;Del.;D.C.;Fla.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Miss.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;Tenn.;Tex.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis. |reference=None |publication title=Sp. Pl. |publication year=1753 |special status=Illustrated;Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_39.xml |genus=Aletris |species=Aletris farinosa }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aletris]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aletris lutea |accepted_authority=Small |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. New York Bot. Gard. |place=1: 278. 1896 |year=1896 }} |common_names=Yellow colic-root |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Liliaceae;Aletris;Aletris lutea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Liliaceae]]
genus[[Aletris]]
species[[Aletris lutea]]
|volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 65 |treatment_page=page 66 }}Leaves 7–18 × 1–2.6 cm; blade bright green, linear to lanceolate. Scape 5–10 dm. Flowers: perianth usually yellow to golden yellow, rarely white, cylindrical, 9–12 mm, more than 2.5 times as long as broad, lobes spreading. Fruits: beaks gradually narrowed distally. 2n = 26.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring. |habitat=Seasonally wet to flooded pine flatwoods, savannas, bogs |elevation=0 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss. |discussion=

A white-flowered form of Aletris lutea was described as forma albiflora E. T. Browne. Hybrids of A. lutea × obovata occur commonly in intermixed populations and have pale yellow corollas of intermediate shape (V. I. Sullivan 1973). These hybrids have been named as A. ×tottenii E. T. Browne.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aletris lutea |authority=Small |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Liliaceae |phenology=Flowering spring. |habitat=Seasonally wet to flooded pine flatwoods, savannas, bogs |elevation=0 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;Ga.;La.;Miss. |reference=None |publication title=Bull. New York Bot. Gard. |publication year=1896 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_41.xml |genus=Aletris |species=Aletris lutea }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aletris]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Aletris obovata |accepted_authority=Nash ex Small |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=in J. K. Small, Fl. S.E. U.S., |place=286. 1903 |year=1903 }} |common_names=White colic-root |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=E |label=Endemic }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Liliaceae;Aletris;Aletris obovata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Liliaceae]]
genus[[Aletris]]
species[[Aletris obovata]]
|volume=Volume 26 |mention_page=page 65 |treatment_page=page 66 }}Leaves 3–13 × 1–2.8 cm; blade bright green, elliptic to lanceolate. Scape 4–7 dm. Flowers: perianth white to creamy white, sometimes tipped with orange or pinkish orange, campanulate or obovoid, 7–11 mm, lobes turned slightly inward (see note under 4. Aletris lutea). Fruits: beaks abruptly narrowed distally. 2n = 26.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Moist pine flatwoods and savannas, roadside ditches |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;Ga.;Miss.;S.C. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Aletris obovata |authority=Nash ex Small |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Liliaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–mid summer. |habitat=Moist pine flatwoods and savannas, roadside ditches |elevation=0–100 m |distribution=Ala.;Fla.;Ga.;Miss.;S.C. |reference=None |publication title=in J. K. Small, Fl. S.E. U.S., |publication year=1903 |special status=Endemic |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V26/V26_40.xml |genus=Aletris |species=Aletris obovata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Aletris]]

revision.comment: Fixed text and links in key to match printed volume
revision.text:
{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alisma |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 343. 1753; Gen. Pl. ed. 5; 160, 1754 |year=1754 }} |common_names=Water-plantain |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Alismataceae;Alisma |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Alismataceae]]
genus[[Alisma]]
|etymology=ancient Greek name, adopted by Linnaeus from Dioscorides |volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs, perennial, submersed, floating-leaved, emersed, glabrous; rhizomes often present; stolons absent; corms absent; tubers absent. Roots not septate. Leaves sessile or petiolate; petiole triangular; blade with translucent markings absent, linear to ovate, base attenuate to rounded, margins entire, apex obtuse to acute. Inflorescences panicles, of 2–10 whorls, erect, emersed, rarely submersed; bracts delicate, smooth, apex acuminate, surfaces smooth. Flowers bisexual; pedicels ascending; bracts subtending pedicels, lanceolate, shorter than pedicels, apex acuminate; receptacle flattened; sepals erect, not sculptured, herbaceous; petals pink or white, entire; stamens 6–9, filaments filiform, glabrous; pistils 15–20, in ring around margin of flattened receptacle, not radiating in starlike pattern, distinct; ovules 1; styles lateral. Fruits without longitudinal ribs, strongly laterally compressed, abaxial wings absent, lateral wings absent, abaxially 2–3-ribbed, abaxial keel absent, glands absent. x = 7.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Widely distributed;nearly worldwide. |discussion=

Much controversy surrounds the treatment of Alisma in North America. At present three distinct native species in North America are generally recognized (P. Rubtzoff 1964) as well as the probable occurrence of two introduced species, one in California and the other in Alaska.

Species 9 (5 in the flora).

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=bj1968a |text=Björkquist, I. 1968. Studies in Alisma L. II. Chromosome studies, crossing experiments and taxonomy. Opera Bot. 19: 1--138. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=hendricks1957a |text=Hendricks, A. J. 1957. A revision of the genus Alisma (Dill.) L. Amer. Midl. Naturalist 58: 470--493. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=rubtzoff1964a |text=Rubtzoff, P. 1964. Notes on the genus Alisma. Leafl. W. Bot. 10: 90--95. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=voss1958a |text=Voss, E. G. 1958. Confusion in Alisma. Taxon 7: 130--133. }} }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |- id="key-0-1" |1 |Style longer than or (equal to) ovary; anthers ellipsoid. |[[#key-0-2| > 2]] |- id="key-0-1" |1 |Style shorter than or (equal to) ovary; anthers ovoid to rounded. |[[#key-0-3| > 3]] |- id="key-0-2" |2 |Petals with obtuse apex, purplish white to purplish pink; style ± straight; leaf blade ovate to broadly lanceolate; Alaska. |[[Alisma plantago-aquatica]] |- id="key-0-2" |2 |Petals with acute apex, purplish pink; style curved proximally; leaf blade narrowly elliptic to lanceolate; California. |[[Alisma lanceolatum]] |- id="key-0-3" |3 |Achenes with 2 abaxial grooves, 1 abaxial ridge; leaves submersed, ribbonlike, or if emersed, blades linear-lanceolate to narrowly elliptic. |[[Alisma gramineum]] |- id="key-0-3" |3 |Achenes with1 abaxial groove; leaves emersed, rarely submersed or floating, blades ovate to elliptic. |[[#key-0-4| > 4]] |- id="key-0-4" |4 |Fruiting heads 2–4 mm diam.; achenes 1.5–2.2 mm; petals 1–3 mm. |[[Alisma subcordatum]] |- id="key-0-4" |4 |Fruiting heads 4.1–7 mm diam.; achenes 2.1–3 mm; petals 3.5–6 mm. |[[Alisma triviale]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Alisma |authority=Linnaeus |rank=genus |parent rank=family |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Alismataceae |distribution=Widely distributed;nearly worldwide. |reference=bj1968a;hendricks1957a;rubtzoff1964a;voss1958a |publication title=Sp. Pl. |publication year=1754 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_229.xml |genus=Alisma }} [[Category:Treatment]] [[Category:Alismataceae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alisma gramineum |accepted_authority=Lejeune |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Flore des Environs de Spa |place=1: 175. 1811 |year=1811 }} |common_names=Grass-leaved water-plantain;alisma graminoide |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alisma geyeri |authority=Torrey |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alisma gramineum var. angustissimum |authority=A. J. Hendricks |rank=variety }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alisma gramineum var. wahlenbergii |authority=Raymond & Kucyniak |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Alismataceae;Alisma;Alisma gramineum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Alismataceae]]
genus[[Alisma]]
species[[Alisma gramineum]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs, 0.5–30(–50) cm. Leaves submersed, floating, or emersed; submersed sessile, ribbonlike; floating linear, 15–100 × 0.2–2(–3) cm, blade present or absent; emersed petiolate, rarely sessile, blade linear-lanceolate, lanceolate, or narrowly elliptic, 4–2–6 × 1.5 cm. Inflorescences to 50 cm. Flowers cleistogamous in submersed plants, chasmogamous in terrestrial; sepals 1.5–3 mm; petals faint purplish white, 2–4 mm, margin entire to slightly erose, apex obtuse; anthers ovoid, 0.3–0.6 mm; style ± coiled, 0.4–0.5 mm, ½ length ovary. Fruiting heads 3–6 mm diam.; achenes orbicular to orbicular-ovoid, 2–2.7 mm, with 2 shallow, abaxial grooves lateral to 1 abaxial ridge, beak erect. 2n =14.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering summer–fall. |habitat=Shallow fresh or brackish water or muddy shores |elevation=30–1800 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;Nev.;N.Y.;N.Dak.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Vt.;Wash.;Wyo.;Eurasia;n Africa. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alisma gramineum |authority=Lejeune |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Alisma geyeri;Alisma gramineum var. angustissimum;Alisma gramineum var. wahlenbergii |basionyms= |family=Alismataceae |phenology=Flowering summer–fall. |habitat=Shallow fresh or brackish water or muddy shores |elevation=30–1800 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;Ont.;Que.;Sask.;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Idaho;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;Nev.;N.Y.;N.Dak.;Oreg.;S.Dak.;Utah;Vt.;Wash.;Wyo.;Eurasia;n Africa. |reference=None |publication title=Flore des Environs de Spa |publication year=1811 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_109.xml |genus=Alisma |species=Alisma gramineum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alisma]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alisma lanceolatum |accepted_authority=Withering |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=An Arrangement of British Plants (ed. 3) |place=2: 362. 1796 |year=1796 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Alismataceae;Alisma;Alisma lanceolatum |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Alismataceae]]
genus[[Alisma]]
species[[Alisma lanceolatum]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs, to 70 cm. Leaves emersed, petiolate; blade lanceolate, 6–23 × 1–4.5 cm. Inflorescences to 70 cm. Flowers chasmogamous; sepals 1.6–3 mm; petals purplish pink, 4.4–6.5 mm, margins ± erose, apex acuminate; anthers ellipsoid, 0.6–1.1 mm; style ± curved, 0.4–0.6 mm, equaling ovary length. Fruiting heads 4–8 mm diam; achenes obovoid, 2–2.9 mm, with 1–2 abaxial grooves, beak erect. 2n = 26, 28 (Eurasian material).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering and fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Streams and marshes |elevation=0–500 m |distribution=Calif.;Oreg. |introduced=true |tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=baldwin1955a |text=Baldwin, J. T. and B. M. Speese. 1955. Chromosomes of taxa of the Alismataceae in the range of Gray’s Manual. Amer. J. Bot. 42: 406--411. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=brown1946a |text=Brown, W. V. 1946. Cytological studies in the Alismaceae. Bot. Gaz. 108: 262--267. should that be Alismataceae??---ed. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=heiser1948a |text=Heiser, C. B. and T. W. Whitaker. 1948. Chromosome number, polyploidy and growth habit in California weeds. Amer. J. Bot. 35: 179--186. }}{{Treatment/Reference |id=l1981a |text=Löve, Á. and D. Löve. 1981. In: IOPB chromosome number reports LXXII. Taxon 30: 694--708. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Alisma lanceolatum |authority=Withering |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Alismataceae |phenology=Flowering and fruiting summer–fall. |habitat=Streams and marshes |elevation=0–500 m |distribution=Calif.;Oreg. |introduced=true |reference=baldwin1955a;brown1946a;heiser1948a;l1981a |publication title=An Arrangement of British Plants (ed. 3) |publication year=1796 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_35.xml |genus=Alisma |species=Alisma lanceolatum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alisma]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alisma plantago-aquatica |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Sp. Pl. |place=1: 342. 1753 |year=1753 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }} |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Alismataceae;Alisma;Alisma plantago-aquatica |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Alismataceae]]
genus[[Alisma]]
species[[Alisma plantago-aquatica]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs, to 1 m. Leaves emersed, petiolate; blade linear-lanceolate to broadly elliptic to ovate, to 30 × 1–12 cm. Inflorescences to 1 m. Flowers chasmogamous; sepals 1.7–3.2 mm; petals purplish white to purplish pink, 3.4–6.4 mm, margins ± erose, apex obtuse; anthers ellipsoid, 0.7–1.4 mm; style ± straight, 0.6–1.5 mm, exceeding ovary length. Fruiting heads 4–6.5 mm diam; achenes ovoid, 1.7–3.1 mm, abaxial keels broadly rounded, with 1 median abaxial groove, rarely 2, beak erect or nearly erect. 2n = 14 (Eurasian material).{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering and fruiting late summer. |habitat=Stream margins |elevation=200 m |distribution=Alaska;Eurasia. |introduced=true |discussion=

The name Alisma plantago-aquatica has been used in a variety of North American floras. We are following, however, the treatment of I. Björkqvist (1968), in which the native distribution of A. plantago-aquatica is restricted to Eurasia.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=fernald1946a |text=Fernald, M. L. 1946. The North American representatives of Alisma plantago-aquatica. Pl. |publication year=1753 |special status=Introduced |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_221.xml |genus=Alisma |species=Alisma plantago-aquatica }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alisma]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alisma subcordatum |accepted_authority=Rafinesque |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Medical Repository |place=hexade 2, 5:354. 1808 |year=1808 }} |common_names=Southern water-plantain;alisma subcorde |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alisma parviflorum |authority=Pursh |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alisma plantago-aquatica var. parviflorum |authority=(Pursh) Torrey |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Alismataceae;Alisma;Alisma subcordatum |hierarchy_nav=

genus[[Alisma]]
species[[Alisma subcordatum]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs, to 6 dm. Leaves emersed, rarely floating, petiolate; blade ovate to elliptic, to 15 × 10 cm. Inflorescences to 1 m. Flowers chasmogamous; sepals 1.5–2.5(–6) mm; petals white, 1–3 mm, margins slightly erose, apex mostly acuminate; anthers rounded, 0.4–0.6 mm; style ± curved, 0.2–0.4 mm, ¼ length ovary. Fruiting heads 2–4 mm diam; achenes obliquely ovoid, 1.5–2.2 mm, abaxially rounded, with 1 abaxial groove; beak ascending. 2n =14.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Shallow ponds, stream margins, marshes, and ditches |elevation=50–1500 m |distribution=N.B.;Ont.;Que.;Ala.;Ark.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;D.C.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Vt.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis.;Mexico. |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alisma subcordatum |authority=Rafinesque |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Alisma parviflorum;Alisma plantago-aquatica var. parviflorum |basionyms= |family=Alismataceae |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Shallow ponds, stream margins, marshes, and ditches |elevation=50–1500 m |distribution=N.B.;Ont.;Que.;Ala.;Ark.;Colo.;Conn.;Del.;D.C.;Ga.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;La.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Miss.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Pa.;R.I.;S.C.;S.Dak.;Tenn.;Tex.;Vt.;Va.;W.Va.;Wis.;Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Medical Repository |publication year=1808 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_317.xml |genus=Alisma |species=Alisma subcordatum }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alisma]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alisma triviale |accepted_authority=Pursh |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Flora Americae Septentrionalis |place=1: 252. 1814 |year=1814 }} |common_names=Northern water-plantain;alisma commun |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alisma plantago-aquatica var. americanum |authority=Schultes & Schultes f. |rank=variety }} |hierarchy=Alismataceae;Alisma;Alisma triviale |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Alismataceae]]
genus[[Alisma]]
species[[Alisma triviale]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page= }}Herbs, to 1 m. Leaves emersed, petiolate; blade linear-lanceolate to broadly elliptic or oval, to 35 × 3–12 cm. Inflorescences to 1 m. Flowers chasmogamous; sepals 3–6 mm; petals white, 3.5–6 mm, margins ± erose, apex obtuse; anthers ovoid, 0.6–1 mm; style ± curved, 0.4–0.6 mm, equal to ovary length. Fruiting heads 4.1–7 mm diam; achenes ovoid, 2.1–3 mm, abaxial keel broadly rounded with 1 median abaxial groove, beak erect or nearly erect. 2n = 28.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Shallow muddy ponds, stream margins, marshes, and ditches |elevation=0–2000 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;Nfld. and Labr.;N.W.T.;N.S.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Alaska;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Conn.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Maine;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;Nev.;N.H.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;S.Dak.;Utah;Vt.;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo.;n Mexico. |discussion=

I have seen no specimens from West Virginia, but although the species is to be expected there.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alisma triviale |authority=Pursh |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Alisma plantago-aquatica var. americanum |basionyms= |family=Alismataceae |phenology=Flowering spring–fall. |habitat=Shallow muddy ponds, stream margins, marshes, and ditches |elevation=0–2000 m |distribution=Alta.;B.C.;Man.;N.B.;Nfld. and Labr.;N.W.T.;N.S.;Ont.;P.E.I.;Que.;Sask.;Alaska;Ariz.;Calif.;Colo.;Conn.;Idaho;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Maine;Mass.;Mich.;Minn.;Mont.;Nebr.;Nev.;N.H.;N.Mex.;N.Y.;N.Dak.;Ohio;Okla.;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;S.Dak.;Utah;Vt.;Wash.;Wis.;Wyo.;n Mexico. |reference=None |publication title=Flora Americae Septentrionalis |publication year=1814 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V22/V22_535.xml |genus=Alisma |species=Alisma triviale }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alisma]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alismataceae |accepted_authority=Ventenat |publications= |common_names=Water-plantain or Arrowhead Family |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Alismataceae |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Alismataceae]]
|volume=Volume 22 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 7 }}Herbs, annual or perennial, rhizomatous, stoloniferous, or cormose, caulescent, glabrous to stellate-pubescent; sap milky. Roots septate or not septate. Leaves basal, submersed, floating, or emersed, sessile or petiolate, sheathing proximally; blade with translucent markings of dots or lines present or absent, basal lobes present or absent; venation reticulate, primary veins parallel from base of blade to apex, secondary veins reticulate. Inflorescences scapose racemes or panicles, rarely umbels, erect, rarely floating or decumbent, whorled (forming racemes) or whorls branching (forming panicles), bracteolate. Flowers bisexual or unisexual, if unisexual, staminate and pistillate on same or different plants, hypogynous, subsessile to long-pedicellate; sepals persistent, 3; petals deciduous, 3, delicate; stamens 0, 6, 9, or to 30, distinct; anthers 2-loculed, dehiscing longitudinally; pistils 0 or 6–1500 or more, distinct or coherent proximally, 1-loculed; placentation basal; ovules1–2. Fruits achenes or follicles. Seeds: embryo U-shaped; endosperm absent in mature seed.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Nearly worldwide;primarily tropical and subtropical regions. |discussion=

Genera 12, species ca. 80 (4 genera, 34 species in the flora).

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Allenrolfea |accepted_authority=Kuntze |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Revis. Gen. Pl. |place=2: 545. 1891 |year=1891 }} |common_names=Iodine bush |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Chenopodiaceae;Allenrolfea |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Chenopodiaceae]]
genus[[Allenrolfea]]
|etymology=for Robert Allen Rolfe, English botanist, 1855–1921 |volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 259, 389 |treatment_page=page 321 }}Shrubs, glabrous. Stems erect or decumbent, much-branched, not armed, succulent; branches articulated into small joints. Leaves alternate, ascending, sessile, reduced to scales; blade broadly triangular, base clasping, margins entire, apex acute. Inflorescences terminal spikes, flowers spirally arranged in 3s or 5s in axils of deciduous, peltate, fleshy bracts. Flowers bisexual, sessile; perianth 4–5-lobed, angled, truncate distally, unchanged in fruit; stamens 1–2, exserted; stigmas 2(–3), usually distinct. Fruits utricles, ovoid, compressed; pericarp free, membranous. Seeds erect, brown or reddish brown, oblong, smooth; embryo partly enclosing copious perisperm, radicle inferior. x = 9.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=North America;Mexico;Central America;South America. |discussion=

Species 3 (1 in the flora).

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Allenrolfea |author=Leila M. {{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Allenrolfea occidentalis |accepted_authority=(S. Watson) Kuntze |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Revis. Gen. Pl. |place=2: 546. 1891 |year=1891 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Halostachys occidentalis |authority=S. Watson |rank=species |publication_title=Botany (Fortieth Parallel), |publication_place=293. 1871 }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Chenopodiaceae;Allenrolfea;Allenrolfea occidentalis |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Chenopodiaceae]]
genus[[Allenrolfea]]
species[[Allenrolfea occidentalis]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 322, 335 |treatment_page=page 321 }}Plants 3–15 dm, ± glaucous. Stems woody proximally, fleshy distally; articulations (joints) (2–)3–5(–10) × 1–4.5 mm. Leaves deciduous; blade 2–4 × 2–3 mm. Inflorescences 6–25 × 2.5–4 mm. Utricles enclosed by perianth. Seeds ca. 0.6 mm.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering mid summer–late fall. |habitat=Alkaline soils, mostly on raised sandy hummocks in salt playas and mud flats |elevation=1000-1700 m |distribution=Ariz.;Calif.;Idaho;N.Mex.;Nev.;Oreg.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico. |discussion=

A dominant shrub of salt playas and mudflats in the American Southwest, iodine bush is easily distinguished from great distances by the dark hue of its stems. The blackish-colored shrubs stand in stark contrast to surrounding vegetation and on close examination can be easily distinguished from the opposite-branched, but vegetatively similar members of Sarcocornia.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Allenrolfea occidentalis |authority=(S. Gen. Pl. |publication year=1891 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_623.xml |genus=Allenrolfea |species=Allenrolfea occidentalis }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Allenrolfea]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alliaria |accepted_authority=Heister ex Fabricius |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Enum., |place=161. 1759 |year=1759 }} |common_names=Garlic mustard |basionyms= |synonyms= |hierarchy=Brassicaceae;Brassicaceae tribe Thlaspideae;Alliaria |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Brassicaceae]]
tribe[[Brassicaceae tribe Thlaspideae]]
genus[[Alliaria]]
|etymology=Genus Allium, garlic or onion, and Latin –aria, connection, alluding to odor of crushed plant |volume=Volume 7 |mention_page=page 234, 246 |treatment_page=page 744 }}Plants with garlic smell when crushed; not scapose; glabrous or pubescent, trichomes simple. Stems erect [decumbent], often branched distally. Leaves basal and cauline; petiolate; basal (often withered by anthesis or fruiting), rosulate, long-petiolate, blade margins crenate, dentate, or sinuate; cauline shortly petiolate, blade margins dentate. Racemes elongated in fruit. Fruiting pedicels divaricate or ascending, stout (almost as broad as fruit [slender, narrower than fruit]). Flowers: sepals erect, oblong, lateral pair not saccate basally, (glabrous); petals oblanceolate, (longer than sepals), claw obscurely differentiated from blade, (apex obtuse); stamens slightly tetradynamous; filaments not dilated basally; anthers ovate or oblong, (apex obtuse); nectar glands confluent, subtending bases of stamens. Fruits siliques, sessile, linear [oblong], torulose or subtorulose, terete, subterete, or 4-angled; valves each with prominent midvein and distinct marginal veins, glabrous [scabrous]; replum rounded; septum complete; ovules [4–]6–22 per ovary; style obsolete or distinct (to 6 mm); stigma capitate, entire. Seeds plump, not winged, oblong; seed coat (longitudinally striate), not mucilaginous when wetted; cotyledons incumbent.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=Eurasia;n Africa. |introduced=true |discussion=

Species 2 (1 in the flora).

Alliaria brachycarpa M. Bieberstein is endemic to Caucasus.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=cavers1979a |text=Cavers, P. B., M. I. Heagy, and R. F. Kokron. 1979. The biology of Canadian weeds. 35. Alliaria petiolata (M. Bieb.) Cavara and Grande. Canad. J. Pl. Sci. 59: 217–229. }} }}{{#Taxon: name=Alliaria |author=Ihsan A. Al-Shehbaz |authority=Heister ex Fabricius |rank=genus |parent rank=tribe |synonyms= |basionyms= |family=Brassicaceae |distribution=Eurasia;n Africa. |introduced=true |reference=cavers1979a |publication title=Enum., |publication year=1759 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V7/V7_1310.xml |tribe=Brassicaceae tribe Thlaspideae |genus=Alliaria }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Brassicaceae tribe Thlaspideae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Alliaria petiolata |accepted_authority=(M. Bieberstein) Cavara & Grande |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Bull. Orto Bot. Regia Univ. Napoli |place=3: 418. 1913 |year=1913 }} |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=W |label=Weedy }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=I |label=Introduced }}{{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Arabis petiolata |authority=M. Bieberstein |rank=species |publication_title=Fl. Taur.-Cauc. |publication_place=2: 126. 1808 }} |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Alliaria officinalis |authority=Andrzejowski ex M. Bieberstein |rank=species }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Erysimum alliaria |authority=Linnaeus |rank=species }} |hierarchy=Brassicaceae;Brassicaceae tribe Thlaspideae;Alliaria;Alliaria petiolata |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Brassicaceae]]
tribe[[Brassicaceae tribe Thlaspideae]]
genus[[Alliaria]]
species[[Alliaria petiolata]]
|volume=Volume 7 |mention_page= |treatment_page=page 745 }}Stems simple or branched distally, (1.5–)3–9(–13) dm; glabrous or pilose basally, trichomes to 1.5 mm. Basal leaves: petiole 3–16(–22) cm; blade reniform or cordate, (6–)15–88(–118) mm wide (shorter in length), surfaces glabrous or pilose. Cauline leaves: petiole shorter than basal; blade ovate, cordate, or deltate, to 15 × 15 cm, base cordate or truncate, margins acutely to obtusely toothed, apex acute. Racemes several-flowered. Fruiting pedicels terete, (2–)3–10(–15) mm. Flowers: sepals (2–)2.5–3.5(–4.5) × 0.7–1.5 mm; petals (2.5–)4–8(–9) × (1.5–)2–3(–3.5) mm, base attenuate to clawlike; filaments 2–3.5(–4.5) mm; anthers oblong, 0.7–1 mm. Fruits divaricate-ascending, subtorulose, quadrangular or subterete, (2–)3–7(–8) cm × 1.2–2.5 mm; style (0.2–)1–2(–3) mm. Seeds dark brown or black, narrowly oblong, 2–4.5 × 0.7–2 mm. 2n = 42.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering Apr–May. |habitat=Roadsides, trails, railroad tracks, stream banks, waste places, fields, shaded woodlands, bluffs, thickets, steep slopes, disturbed fields, floodplains, woods, shaded forest floor |elevation=0-1200 m |distribution=B.C.;Ont.;Conn.;Del.;D.C.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Ohio;Okla.;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;Tenn.;Utah;Vt.;Va.;Wash.;W.Va.;Wis.;South America (Argentina);Eurasia;n Africa. |introduced=true |tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Alliaria petiolata |authority=(M. Bieberstein) Cavara & Grande |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms=Alliaria officinalis;Erysimum alliaria |basionyms=Arabis petiolata |family=Brassicaceae |phenology=Flowering Apr–May. |habitat=Roadsides, trails, railroad tracks, stream banks, waste places, fields, shaded woodlands, bluffs, thickets, steep slopes, disturbed fields, floodplains, woods, shaded forest floor |elevation=0-1200 m |distribution=B.C.;Ont.;Conn.;Del.;D.C.;Ill.;Ind.;Iowa;Kans.;Ky.;Maine;Md.;Mass.;Mich.;Mo.;Nebr.;N.H.;N.J.;N.Y.;N.C.;Ohio;Okla.;Oreg.;Pa.;R.I.;Tenn.;Utah;Vt.;Va.;Wash.;W.Va.;Wis.;South America (Argentina);Eurasia;n Africa. |introduced=true |reference=None |publication title=Bull. Orto Bot. Regia Univ. Napoli |publication year=1913 |special status=Weedy;Introduced;Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V7/V7_1311.xml |tribe=Brassicaceae tribe Thlaspideae |genus=Alliaria |species=Alliaria petiolata }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Alliaria]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Allionia |accepted_authority=Linnaeus |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Syst. Nat. ed. |place=10, 2: 890. 1759 |year=1759 }} |basionyms= |synonyms={{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Wedelia |authority=Loefling |rank=genus }} {{Treatment/ID/Synonym |name=Wedeliella |authority=Cockerell |rank=genus }} |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Allionia |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Allionia]]
|etymology=For C. Allioni, 1725–1804, Italian botanist |volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 14, 16, 50 |treatment_page=page 58 }}Herbs, annual or perennial, finely pubescent, often somewhat viscid; taproot slender and soft to stout and woody (depending on duration). Stems procumbent, often clambering through other vegetation, unarmed, without glutinous bands on internodes. Leaves paired, petiolate, unequal, blades thin, base ± asymmetric. Inflorescences axillary, pedunculate, clusters of 3 simultaneously blooming flowers resembling single flower; bracts persistent, not accrescent, 3, forming involucre, distinct, broadly ovate, cucullate, thin, translucent. Flowers bisexual, chasmogamous; perianth strongly bilaterally symmetric, funnelform but strongly oblique, constricted beyond ovary, gradually expanded, adaxial lobes minute, abaxially forming a fan-shaped limb; stamens 4–7, ± exserted; styles exserted beyond stamens; stigmas capitate. Fruits oblong to somewhat obovate, dorsoventrally compressed (adaxial face convex, internal, in inflorescence), with 5 strongly modified ribs, central adaxial rib an inconspicuous to pronounced rib or ridge, sometimes toothed, keeled, coriaceous; 2 lateral ribs expanded and incurved toward concave side as wings or teeth; 2 ribs on concave surface forming low, thin ridge, often with teeth that usually bear glands at tip, surface glabrous, and smooth or the adaxial slightly rugose.{{Treatment/Body |distribution=sw United States;Mexico;Central America;West Indies;South America. |discussion=

Species 2 (2 in the flora).

The two species of Allionia are very similar, differing primarily in the nature and number of teeth on the fruit. In many floras for areas south of the United States only a single species, Allionia incarnata, is recognized. When sympatric, the two species are distinguishable by vegetative and perianth features, but throughout their ranges, the two species cannot be consistently distinguished by the same characteristics. Nevertheless, as noted by B. L. Turner (1994), plants with intergradient fruits are uncommon. Both species may produce fruits with lateral ribs that are curved and winglike, without teeth; this condition is frequent in A. incarnata in North America and occasional in A. choisyi in South America.

The three bilaterally symmetric flowers in the Allionia inflorescence bloom synchronously and are sufficiently closely situated that the entire inflorescence resembles a single radially symmetric flower. The fruit is among the most complex in the family. The convex side, oriented toward the center of the cluster of three flowers, exudes copious mucilage when wetted. The viscid glands on the concave surface remain sticky for decades in the herbarium.

|tables= |references={{Treatment/Reference |id=turner1994a |text=Turner, B. L. 1994. Revisionary study of the genus Allionia (Nyctaginaceae). Phytologia 77: 45–55. }} }}
==Key==
{| class="wikitable fna-keytable" |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Fruits deeply convex adaxially; lateral ribs developed as curved wings with 0-4 irregular or regular triangular teeth; viscid glands on concave side on stalks usually equaling or shorter than diameter of glandular head |[[Allionia incarnata|Allionia incarnata]] |-id=key-0-1 |1 |Fruits shallowly convex adaxially; lateral ribs developed as curved wings with 4-8 slender teeth; viscid glands on concave side on stalks usually equaling or longer than diameter of glandular head |[[Allionia choisyi|Allionia choisyi]] |}
{{#Taxon: name=Allionia |author=Richard W. Spellenberg |authority=Linnaeus |rank=genus |parent rank=family |synonyms=Wedelia;Wedeliella |basionyms= |family=Nyctaginaceae |illustrator=Barbara Alongi |illustration copyright=Flora of North America Association |distribution=sw United States;Mexico;Central America;West Indies;South America. |reference=turner1994a |publication title=Syst. Nat. ed. |publication year=1759 |special status= |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_113.xml |genus=Allionia }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Nyctaginaceae]]

{{Treatment/ID |accepted_name=Allionia choisyi |accepted_authority=Standley |publications={{Treatment/Publication |title=Publ. Field Mus. Nat. Hist., Bot. Ser. |place=8: 310. 1931 |year=1931 }} |common_names=Trailing four-o’clock;umbrella-wort;garapatilla |special_status={{Treatment/ID/Special_status |code=F |label=Illustrated }} |basionyms={{Treatment/ID/Basionym |name=Allionia incarnata var. glabra |authority=Choisy |rank=variety |publication_title=in A. P. de Candolle and A. L. P. P. de Candolle, Prodr. |publication_place=13(2): 435. 1849, }} |synonyms= |hierarchy=Nyctaginaceae;Allionia;Allionia choisyi |hierarchy_nav=
family[[Nyctaginaceae]]
genus[[Allionia]]
species[[Allionia choisyi]]
|volume=Volume 4 |mention_page=page 58, 59 |treatment_page=page 60 }}Herbs, annual [probably also perennial], glabrate to viscid pubescent. Stems often reddish, 0.1–0.7[–2] m. Leaves progressively reduced distally; distal leaves proportionately narrower than proximal; larger leaves: petiole 2–18[–30] mm, equaling or shorter than blade; blade usually undulate, sometimes flat, 10–30 × 6–22 mm, base often oblique, obtuse, or round, margins sinuate, sometimes entire, apex narrowing to rounded tip, obtuse, or acute. Inflorescences: peduncle 1–9(–12) mm; involucres broadly ovoid to spheric when mature, 4–7.5 mm. Perianth pale pink to magenta [nearly white], 2–7 mm. Fruits shallowly convex, 3.2–4.3 × 1.8–3.7 mm; lateral ribs with 4–8 teeth, teeth slender and attenuate, sometimes gland tipped [rarely mostly entire with short-toothed margin], concave side of fruit with 5–7 glands per row; stalk equaling or longer than diameter of glandular head.{{Treatment/Body |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall [year-round]. |habitat=Open arid areas, often on sandy or gravelly soils, sometimes on clay or gypsum |elevation=[0-]800-1600[-2500] m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America. |discussion=

The low, broad fruit of Allionia choisyi resembles a small, clinging tick, hence the Spanish name “garapatilla.” Occasionally the fruits are strongly convex, others may have four moderately slender teeth; in either case the fruits are intergradient to the few-toothed, strongly convex fruits of A. incarnata. Such plants are most commonly found in southeastern Arizona and in arid south-central Texas. Plants with fruits shaped as those in A. choisyi, with glands on the concave surface with tall stalks but with entire or nearly entire, curved, lateral ribs occur occasionally in South America. Collectors have noted that A. choisyi plants hug the ground more closely than those of A. incarnata. Throughout much of its range in North America, A. choisyi has leaves with strongly pleated-undulate blades. Very small, pale pink to white flowers are also more common in A. choisyi, especially in Mexico.

In the flora area Allionia choisyi is usually an annual. In Mexico, plants often appear to be perennial.

|tables= |references= }}{{#Taxon: name=Allionia choisyi |authority=Standley |rank=species |parent rank=genus |synonyms= |basionyms=Allionia incarnata var. glabra |family=Nyctaginaceae |phenology=Flowering late spring–early fall [year-round]. |habitat=Open arid areas, often on sandy or gravelly soils, sometimes on clay or gypsum |elevation=[0-]800-1600[-2500] m |distribution=Ariz.;N.Mex.;Tex.;Utah;Mexico;West Indies;Central America;South America. |reference=None |publication title=Publ. Field Mus. Nat. Hist., Bot. Ser. |publication year=1931 |special status=Illustrated |source xml=https://bitbucket.org/aafc-mbb/fna-data-curation/src/2e0870ddd59836b60bcf96646a41e87ea5a5943a/coarse_grained_fna_xml/V4/V4_117.xml |genus=Allionia |species=Allionia choisyi }}[[Category:Treatment]][[Category:Allionia]]
